news.title: Bocelli concerto, canto d’amore sotto la luna di Pompei

collectionItem.title: Bocelli concerto, canto d’amore sotto la luna di Pompei

data.summary:
Il Mattino reviews Maestro Andrea Bocelli’s concert in the Pompeii amphitheatre, describing the evening as a “triumph” and a “huge success.”

Among the cast of singers and musicians invited to perform alongside the Maestro were two Bocelli-Jameel scholars: Clara Barbier Serrano (2020) and Laura Mekhail (2021).

Il Mattino writes: “Serena Gamberoni, Clara Barbier Serrano, Aigerim Altynbek and Laura Mekhail are the four sopranos called upon to offer a crucial interlocution to the evening's undisputed star.”

news.title: Africa rises to combat drought and desertification

collectionItem.title: Africa rises to combat drought and desertification

data.summary:
The African Union estimates that 485 million people on the continent are directly affected by land degradation, with droughts accounting for over 44% of all global drought-related disasters.

Tahira Mohamed, a research fellow at the Jameel Observatory for Food Security Early Action, told CGTN Africa that while climate change is the primary driver for droughts, a critical gap remains in disaster preparedness:

“What we need is goodwill from the government, embedding the anticipatory action planning for drought management and also financing, because if you don't finance then the early warnings will not be useful.”

news.title: Esther Duflo, Prix Nobel d’économie : « L’aide au développement n’est pas un gaspillage d’argent public »

collectionItem.title: Esther Duflo, Prix Nobel d’économie : « L’aide au développement n’est pas un gaspillage d’argent public »

data.summary:
In an op-ed for Le Monde, Esther Duflo (J-PAL) argues that development aid is not a waste of public money, highlighting the progress of poor countries in recent decades and the role of foreign aid in proving innovative, successful development strategies.

Esther writes: “The credit for this goes primarily to the governments and people of these countries.

“But development aid from rich countries has also played an important role in strengthening global public goods, overcoming crises and rigorously testing and evaluating innovative approaches.”
data.arabicTitle: إستر دوفلو، الحائزة على جائزة نوبل في الاقتصاد: "مساعدات التنمية ليست إهدارًا للمال العام"

news.title: Egyptian school revives traditional and heritage crafts

collectionItem.title: Egyptian school revives traditional and heritage crafts

data.summary:
Reuters features the Jameel House of Traditional Arts in Cairo in a report on the school’s revival of Egyptian heritage crafts.

Highlighting how the programme is reinvigorating traditional arts for a new generation, Reuters interviewed Mamdouh Sakr, programme director of the Jameel House in Cairo, who explained:

“There are over 200 graduates from the Jameel House, and our goal from the beginning, we had several goals: to preserve the heritage and traditional crafts, to train people on them and teach them, and at the same time to be able to tackle traditional and heritage crafts in a somewhat contemporary way.”

news.title: The Jameel House graduates a new generation of Egyptian craftspeople

collectionItem.title: The Jameel House graduates a new generation of Egyptian craftspeople

data.summary:
Al-Arab highlights the Jameel House of Traditional Arts in Cairo for its revival of heritage crafts in Egypt.

Focusing on the programme’s human impact, the article looks at how the Jameel House in Cairo provides opportunities to women who face difficulties learning traditional arts.

Noha El-Qahwagy, head of the Jameel House in Cairo’s copper and metals department, explains: “Copper is an authentic material that has always been associated with our homes.

“I had been trying to find a way to learn this craft since school, but most workshops refused to train women. I searched for a long time until I found the right environment at the Jameel House.”

news.title: The retreat from aid is a costly mistake

collectionItem.title: The retreat from aid is a costly mistake

data.summary:
Speaking The Washington Post, Esther Duflo and Abhijit Banerjee (J-PAL) point to evidence that, over the last 25 years, aid has improved living standards for the world’s poorest faster than expected.

Professor Duflo says: “There has been a tremendous amount of progress, often without much outside money.”

news.title: RED NOSES to explore the impact of healthcare clowning in Lesvos, in collaboration with the Jameel Arts & Health Lab and WHO Europe

collectionItem.title: RED NOSES to explore the impact of healthcare clowning in Lesvos, in collaboration with the Jameel Arts & Health Lab and WHO Europe

data.summary:
RED NOSES announces a new collabration with the Jameel Arts and Health Lab and the World Health Organisation regional office for Europe to explore the impact of healthcare clowning in Lesvos, Greece, from 2025-2027.

A pioneering research study will evaluate the effectiveness of the clowns’ artistic interventions on the wellbeing and social connectedness of unaccompanied minors and aid workers supporting forced migrants.

Lesvos has experienced a surge in refugees since 2024, with studies showing that up to 87% of refugees experience anxiety, depression and related symptoms.

Alongside the pressure and stress placed on aid workers, this demonstrates the need for enhanced psychosocial support that the collaboration hopes to provide.

news.title: J-WAFS Solutions: Translating Water and Food Research into Tangible Solutions for Global Challenges

collectionItem.title: J-WAFS Solutions: Translating Water and Food Research into Tangible Solutions for Global Challenges

data.summary:
SUGGESTIONS OR FEEDBACK? HOW J-WAFS SOLUTIONS GRANTS BRING RESEARCH TO MARKET

For the Abdul Latif Jameel Water and Food Systems Lab (J-WAFS), 2025 marks a decade of translating groundbreaking research into tangible solutions for global challenges. Few examples illustrate that mission better than NONA Technologies. With support from a J-WAFS Solutions grant, MIT electrical engineering and biological engineering Professor Jongyoon Han and his team developed a portable desalination device that transforms seawater into clean drinking water without filters or high-pressure pumps. The device stands apart from traditional systems because conventional desalination technologies, like reverse osmosis, are energy-intensive, prone to fouling, and typically deployed at large, centralized plants. In contrast, the device developed in Han's lab employs ion concentration polarization technology to remove salts and particles from seawater, producing potable water that exceeds World Health Organization standards. It is compact, solar-powered, and operable at the push of a button - making it an ideal solution for off-grid and disaster-stricken areas.

This research laid the foundation for spinning out NONA Technologies along with co-founders Junghyo Yoon, a former postdoc in Han's lab, and Bruce Crawford MBA '23, to commercialize the technology and address pressing water-scarcity issues worldwide. "This is really the culmination of a 10-year journey that I and my group have been on," said Han in an earlier MIT News article. "We worked for years on the physics behind individual desalination processes, but pushing all those advances into a box, building a system, and demonstrating it in the ocean ... that was a really meaningful and rewarding experience for me." You can watch this video showcasing the device in action.

Moving breakthrough research out of the lab and into the world is a well-known challenge. While traditional "seed" grants typically support early-stage research at Technology Readiness Level (TRL) 1-2, few funding sources exist to help academic teams navigate to the next phase of technology development. The J-WAFS Solutions Program is strategically designed to address this critical gap by supporting technologies in the high-risk, early-commercialization phase that is often neglected by traditional research, corporate, and venture funding. By supporting technologies at TRLs 3-5, the program increases the likelihood that promising innovations will survive beyond the university setting, advancing sufficiently to attract follow-on funding. Equally important, the program gives academic researchers the time, resources, and flexibility to de-risk their technology, explore customer need and potential real-world applications, and determine whether and how they want to pursue commercialization.

For faculty-led teams like Han's, the J-WAFS Solutions Program provided the critical financial runway and entrepreneurial guidance needed to refine the technology, test assumptions about market fit, and lay the foundation for a startup team. While still in the MIT innovation ecosystem, NONA secured over £200

news.title: "Arts for Health & Climate Action: Collaborations and Conversations at Jameel Arts Centre | afikra x Community Jameel COP28 Ep2 Library"

collectionItem.title: "Arts for Health & Climate Action: Collaborations and Conversations at Jameel Arts Centre | afikra x Community Jameel COP28 Ep2 Library"

data.summary:
Arts for Health in the Face of Climate Change: Community Jameel x Afikra COP28 Conversations – Episode 2 

In this live session of the Community Jameel x Afikra COP28 Conversation Series at Jameel Arts Centre, panelists working at the intersection of the arts, health, and climate action explored the important role of art and arts organizations in responding to the climate crisis through the lens of health. The event was held in collaboration with the Jameel Arts Health Lab, a joint effort between Jameel Arts Centre, Nadia Christidi, Uns Kattan, and Dr. Marina Romanello. 

Nadia Christidi, a researcher, writer, and arts practitioner, is currently a PhD candidate in History, Anthropology, and Science, Technology, and Society at MIT. She has a particular interest in how art, design, and architecture can be utilized in future imagining and planning processes. 

Uns Kattan, the deputy director and head of research and learning at Art Jameel, has a strong interest in visual culture and alternative histories. For over ten years, she has worked in various capacities including research, programming, and content development. 

Dr. Marina Romanello, the executive director of the Lancet Countdown and a health researcher at University College London, has a background in clinical biochemistry and biomedical sciences. She is also a member of the working group on health co-benefits in climate change mitigation policies for Italy’s Superior Health Council. 

Dr. Nisha Sajnani, a founding co-director of the Jameel Arts & Health Lab, established in collaboration with the World Health Organization (WHO), New York University (NYU), Community Jameel, and Culturunners, works to improve health and wellbeing through the arts. She is also the director of the program in drama therapy and theatre & health lab, as well as a founding co-director of the Arts & Health @NYU. 

Stephen Stapleton, an artist, social entrepreneur, and founding director of CULTURUNNERS, is known for developing platforms for cultural exchange with the Middle East. He is also a founding co-director of the Jameel Arts & Health Lab, established in collaboration with the WHO, NYU, Community Jameel, and Culturunners. 

Cléa Daridan, the senior curator and cultural lead at Community Jameel, is also a senior lecturer at the École Nationale Supérieure des Arts Décoratifs in Paris. 

This series aims to amplify local communities and foster a more inclusive and informed discussion around climate action. It also seeks to build a forum for intergenerational collaboration and engagement, channeling a unique voice and inspiring thoughtful discussions between youth, experts, non-experts, and key global decision-makers. 

About Our Work: 

We at the Community Jameel x Afikra COP28 Conversations are dedicated to fostering a deeper appreciation for the Arab

news.title: "2025 Winners Announced for Chamber Music Competition in Lyon: Duo Vert Takes Grand Prize"

collectionItem.title: "2025 Winners Announced for Chamber Music Competition in Lyon: Duo Vert Takes Grand Prize"

data.summary:
FRANCE'S CIMCL NAMES 2025 WINNERS

The prestigious Concours International de Musique de Chambre de Lyon (CIMCL) has announced its winners for the year 2025. This year marked the competition's 20th edition, and it focused on the voice-piano duo.

CIMCL, held annually, is known for highlighting different types of chamber music ensembles, such as piano trios, violin-piano duos, and string quartets. The talented musicians compete for various prizes, including the first prize of €8,000, second prize of €6,000, and third prize of €4,000.

Among the winners, Berlin's Duo Vert stood out, comprising bass-baritone Jeeyoung Lim and pianist Cole Knutson. The duo was awarded the first prize of €8,000. London-based Duo Nuvoletta, formed by soprano Clara Barbier Serrano and pianist Joanna Kacperek, won the second prize of €6,000 as well as the Audience Award. They also received the Belle Saison Prize and the Public Prize.

The third prize of €4,000 went to Paris-Tokyo group Duo Musubi, featuring soprano Yui Nanasawa and pianist Kishin Nagai. They also received the €1,000 Prize for Best Performance of Jean-Patrick Besingrand's "Chants du Déversoir." Additionally, the €1,000 SEAM Prize for Commitment to Contemporary Music was awarded to Duo Autekia, formed by tenor Abel Zamora and pianist Félix Moussiegt. The Villecroze Academy Prize was given to soprano Clarisse Dalles and pianist Joseph Birnbaum of Duo Dalles-Birnbaum.

Apart from the cash prizes, CIMCL's Villecroze Academy and Belle Saison Prizes also offer performance opportunities at live events, a Belle Saison tour, entry to the Villecroze Music Academy, and concert engagements with the Royaumont Foundation, Palazzetto Bru Zane, and more.

The jury was made up of esteemed musicians, including Bernarda Fink, Chantal Santon-Jeffery, Markus Hadulla, Mark Padmore, Susan Manoff, and Dietrich Henschel.

Founded in 2023, The Violin Channel is a New York City-based leading international classical music news, media, and streaming platform. With over 600,000+ followers on social media and an email subscription base of over 100,000, it reaches over 2 million readers every month. The platform provides comprehensive coverage of international classical music events, including news, industry updates, masterclasses, competition coverage, interviews, educational resources, events, and concert livestreams. It also focuses on promoting talented young string soloists and ensembles.

The Violin Channel has gained the trust of its 2 million+ monthly

news.title: Can deep learning transform heart failure prevention?

collectionItem.title: Can deep learning transform heart failure prevention?

data.summary:
The MIT Jameel Clinic introduced a new, non-invasive artificial intelligence (AI) tool that can predict a patient’s risk of developing heart disease with gold-standard accuracy, reports MIT News.

Collin Stultz (MIT Jameel Clinic), senior author of a paper on the new tool published in Communications Medicine, adds: “In my view, the real promise of AI in healthcare is to provide equitable, state-of-the-art care to everyone, regardless of their socioeconomic status, background and where they live.

"This work is one step towards realising this goal.”

news.title: New Alliance for Data, Evaluation and Policy Training will advance data-driven decision-making in public policy

collectionItem.title: New Alliance for Data, Evaluation and Policy Training will advance data-driven decision-making in public policy

data.summary:
MIT News reports on J-PAL’s launch of the Alliance for Data, Evaluation and Policy Training (ADEPT), with Community Jameel, on 25 March 2025 in São Paulo, Brazil.

A network of universities, governments and other members, ADEPT will cultivate the next generation of evidence-informed policy professionals through online and in-person courses, academic programmes on policy evaluation and access to the MITx MicroMasters programme in Data, Economics and Design of Policy.

Esther Duflo (J-PAL) explains: “Our aim is to create a vision-driven network of institutions around the world able to equip far more people in far more places with the skills and ambition for evidence-informed policymaking.”

news.title: Family matters: Meet the families with Nobel Prizes

collectionItem.title: Family matters: Meet the families with Nobel Prizes

data.summary:
The Nobel Foundation lists Esther Duflo and Abhijit Banerjee among families who have won Nobel prizes.

In 2019, they shared the Nobel prize in economics with long-time collaborator Michael Kremer for their experimental approach to the alleviation of global poverty.

Esther looks back on their journey: “When I first met Abhijit Banerjee as a first-year student, I found him unbelievably inspiring. He was kind and a bit aloof, but I knew crossing his path had changed my life. Little did I know that many, many years later, I would not only become a colleague, but also, eventually, a life partner.”

news.title: Vocational skills training has multiple benefits

collectionItem.title: Vocational skills training has multiple benefits

data.summary:
The International Monetary Fund cites research by Lisa Corsetto-Poon (J-PAL) in an article exploring the value of vocational skills training.

In the context of high levels of university debt and low student satisfaction, a J-PAL study in Uganda assessed income gains for people given free six-month vocational training.

Lisa noted: “The fact that vocational training is often more accessible, given lower costs to participants and shorter time commitments, means that these programmes could be promising alternatives to university studies.”

news.title: Ultra-low pressure driven RO membrane module for POU with high water permeability and durability

collectionItem.title: Ultra-low pressure driven RO membrane module for POU with high water permeability and durability

data.summary:
Shinshu University reports in The Daily Industrial Newspaper the results of a trial of a new water filter technology, co-conducted by Community Jameel.

The hand-pump device, which is ultra-low pressure for ease of use and incorporates a reverse osmosis membrane filter, exhibited high performance for removing impurities from water, achieving 2.5-3 times higher water permeability than conventional membranes during the trial on the Ganges estuary in West Bengal, India.

news.title: Bird flu 'no longer just an avian virus' as cases found in sheep and cattle

collectionItem.title: Bird flu 'no longer just an avian virus' as cases found in sheep and cattle

data.summary:
Thom Rawson (Jameel Institute) raises concerns regarding the spread of avian influenza following the first ever recorded case of H5N1 among sheep in Yorkshire, England.

Despite the virus recently jumping from birds to mammals, Thom tells The i Paper that the risk level still remains low:

“I do, at least as a scientist working in this field, have confidence that we do have a good eye on what is happening as this picture develops, which is the best position we could be in, and the best we can do then for farmers as well.”

news.title: Especially for the worst off: Talking to Abhijit Banerjee and Esther Duflo

collectionItem.title: Especially for the worst off: Talking to Abhijit Banerjee and Esther Duflo

data.summary:
Abhijit Banerjee and Esther Duflo (J-PAL) sit with The Los Angeles Review of Books following the publication of their book ‘Good economics for hard times’.

They discuss the role of empirical research—particularly randomised controlled trials—in modern economics, as opposed to the traditional conceptual method, before calling for stronger economic “nudging” to mould people’s preferences and values against climate change.

“Progress in behavioural economics has shown that people’s ‘preferences’, particularly on topics they know little about, are largely arbitrary and very easy to influence. Similarly, as creatures of habit, we might feel much more inclined to consume less energy if we see our neighbours consuming less — and these kinds of changes can become systemic and sustainable.”

news.title: As UK cuts aid, we must harness science for humanitarian projects

collectionItem.title: As UK cuts aid, we must harness science for humanitarian projects

data.summary:
In an op-ed for Context, Community Jameel’s director, George Richards, calls for improved collaboration between scientists and humanitarians to enhance the impact of aid, following recent cuts by governments around the world.

George writes: “By combining British expertise in both humanitarianism and science, the government can increase the impact of its funding—stretching the pound. More importantly, a humanitarian response powered by world-class innovations in science and technology can be more effective in caring for people whose lives have been devastated by war and disaster.”

news.title: Women in global health: challenges and progress in leadership

collectionItem.title: Women in global health: challenges and progress in leadership

data.summary:
Katharina Hauck (Jameel Institute) speaks on an international panel of health experts to mark International Women’s Day at Imperial College London.

The panel dealt with the qualities of strong leadership, the importance of challenging the status quo, the barriers women encounter in leadership roles, community-led leadership and the requirements for creating tangible change toward a more equitable future in global health.

On the role of collaboration and teamwork in research, Katharina said: “In academia, it can be very lonely. We are often trained and expected to work on our own, but I believe that true power in academia comes from teamwork and bringing different disciplines together.”

news.title: J-WAFS: Supporting food and water research across MIT

collectionItem.title: J-WAFS: Supporting food and water research across MIT

data.summary:
Speaking to MIT professors about the impact of J-WAFS on the development of their research, MIT News looks back on a decade of food and water innovations and achievements.

2022 J-WAFS Solutions grant recipient Professor Patrick Doyle notes: “Without J-WAFS, I would have never ventured into the field of water purification. Both the funding and the J-WAFS community led me to be deeply engaged in understanding some of the key challenges in water purification and water security."

news.title: Can international aid survive in a crumbling world order?

collectionItem.title: Can international aid survive in a crumbling world order?

data.summary:
In a Financial Times article, Abhijit Banerjee (J-PAL) responds to cuts to international aid, including by the United States and Britain.

Abhijit said: “I hope it’s not a watershed moment, there are many examples where small amounts of money have done huge amounts of good. If the richest countries in the world turn away, we will be left in a world with more misery.”

news.title: Abhijit Banerjee and Esther Duflo: Foreign aid can be effective without the US

collectionItem.title: Abhijit Banerjee and Esther Duflo: Foreign aid can be effective without the US

data.summary:
Writing in The Financial Times, Abhijit Banerjee and Esther Duflo (J-PAL) call for other governments to take the lead on foreign aid following funding cuts by the United States.

The 2019 Nobel prize-winning economists suggest practical policies that can fill gaps exposed by the suspension of USAID funding: “Calculations suggest if billionaires pay a minimum of 2% of their wealth in tax annually, it could raise up to USD 250 billion a year. The US is not necessary to get these policies going.”

news.title: Riyadh Humanitarian Forum: Sustainable and effective solutions to support vulnerable groups

collectionItem.title: Riyadh Humanitarian Forum: Sustainable and effective solutions to support vulnerable groups

data.summary: Okaz’s coverage of the Riyadh International Humanitarian Forum features a session co-hosted by Community Jameel and J-PAL MENA: “The session discussed identifying strategies to enhance the coordination and allocation of resources in humanitarian efforts, and exploring innovative approaches to address complex humanitarian challenges."

news.title: Scientific session entitled: ‘The role of evidence in documenting the impact of humanitarian action’ at the fourth Riyadh International Humanitarian Forum

collectionItem.title: Scientific session entitled: ‘The role of evidence in documenting the impact of humanitarian action’ at the fourth Riyadh International Humanitarian Forum

data.summary: The Saudi Press Agency reports on Community Jameel and J-PAL MENA’s joint panel at the Riyadh International Humanitarian Forum: “The session discussed studying the current status of humanitarian challenges, including the increase in conflict-affected areas, exploring the shift in evidence in humanitarian action, in addition to discussing the importance of identifying cost-effective responses in crisis situations."

news.title: Groundbreaking MIT study challenges common assumptions about sleep

collectionItem.title: Groundbreaking MIT study challenges common assumptions about sleep

data.summary:
Frank Schilbach (J-PAL) is the co-author of an MIT study concluding that more sleep doesn’t necessarily have positive outcomes, reports The Brighter Side.

Despite finding that sleeping for 30 minutes longer every night had no effect on productivity, earnings, financial decision-making, wellbeing, energy levels or health, researchers discovered that participants who napped performed better in several measured categories.

Schilbach explained: “In contrast to the night sleep intervention, we find clear evidence of naps improving a range of outcomes, including their productivity, their cognitive function and their psychological wellbeing, as well as some evidence on savings.”

news.title: Esther Duflo : « J’ai découvert que les économistes avaient un pouvoir dangereux »

collectionItem.title: Esther Duflo : « J’ai découvert que les économistes avaient un pouvoir dangereux »

data.summary:
Esther Duflo sits with Le Monde to discuss her career journey, including co-founding the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) at MIT and winning the Nobel prize in economics with Abhijit Banerjee and Michael Kremer.

Esther highlights the importance of economists making tangible improvements on the world around them, and her pride at achieving this at J-PAL: “I’m proud of it, of having set things up so that others can empower themselves.”

news.title: Une technologie de pointe pour aider les jeunes à identifier les poissons

collectionItem.title: Une technologie de pointe pour aider les jeunes à identifier les poissons

data.summary:
La Gazette de Monaco highlights the educational potential of BRUVS, a baited remote underwater video system deployed in partnership between Community Jameel and the Prince Albert II of Monaco Foundation.

As part of a local school engagement programme, pupils were shown photographs of different marine species and matched them with recordings taken by BRUVS: “Students will thus be able to acquire new knowledge and gain insights on how conservation efforts should be implemented.”

news.title: AI can help fight tax fraud, but is not a silver bullet

collectionItem.title: AI can help fight tax fraud, but is not a silver bullet

data.summary:
Guillermo Herrera Nimmagadda (J-PAL) writes an article for The Hindustan Times tempering expectations that AI will solve the issue of tax fraud without rigorous evaluations.

Guillermo cites J-PAL randomised control trials in Senegal and Ghana to highlight that governments need to be accurate in how and when they employ AI: “There may be higher and quicker returns to simpler technologies that, for instance, improve coordination between tax officials in different jurisdictions.”

The latest edition of your GRAZIA newsletter is on its way to your inbox. As a valued member of our VIP Club, you have access to exclusive giveaways and members only events. And the best part? It's completely free!

In today's news, we're shining a spotlight on some of the most talented female artists in the Middle East. These women are breaking barriers and making waves in the music scene, with their unique sounds and unapologetic voices.

First up is Nemah Hasan, also known as Nemahsis. The Palestinian-Canadian artist gained recognition with her thought-provoking song "what if i took it off for you?" in 2021, sparking important conversations about the hijab in the Muslim community. Despite being dropped by her label in October 2023, Nemahsis made a comeback, using social media and self-advocacy to release her debut album Vertabhim. With her raw and powerful sound, Nemah is paving the way for a new generation of female artists in the Arab world.

Next is Zeyne, a Palestinian-Jordanian singer who is blending Arabic heritage with Western influences. Her debut single "Minni Ana" has gained her global recognition, and her latest track "Balak" (featuring Saint Levant) explores themes of love and longing. Zeyne's music reflects her personal experiences and tackles topics that are not often discussed in her culture, such as mental health and anxiety. With her ability to blend genres and tell compelling stories, Zeyne is a rising star in the Middle Eastern music scene.

Coming from the UAE, we have Almas, an Emirati singer from Khor Fakkan. Inspired by the natural beauty of her hometown, Almas initially focused on traditional Khaleeji pop and Iraqi songs. However, she later started experimenting with rap and producing her own beats, paving the way for a fresh and unique sound. Almas reached new heights when she performed at the Expo 2020 opening, singing the official theme song "This Is Our Time" alongside big names like Hussein Al-Jassmi. She has also become the ambassador for Spotify's Equal Arabia program, solidifying her position as a trailblazer for women in the Arab music scene.

In early 2024, Egyptian soprano Laura Mekhail made her mark on the classical music scene, becoming the first Arab woman to receive the prestigious Bocelli-Jameel scholarship. Despite facing initial concerns from her community, Laura stayed determined to pursue her passion for classical singing and has since performed with Andrea Bocelli and at prestigious venues like the Dubai Opera. Her success story is not only inspirational but is also setting new standards for young Arab women.

news.title: "The Impact of Technology on Modern Society: Exploring the Positive and Negative Effects"

collectionItem.title: "The Impact of Technology on Modern Society: Exploring the Positive and Negative Effects"

data.summary:
The United Kingdom, known for its rich history, diverse cultures, and picturesque landscapes, is a country located in Western Europe. Comprised of England, Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland, this sovereign state is highly regarded for its contributions to art, literature, and sports. From the bustling city streets of London to the tranquil countryside of the Scottish Highlands, there is no shortage of experiences to be had in this magnificent country.

One of the defining aspects of British culture is its long-standing tradition of afternoon tea. This ritual, dating back to the 19th century, is a quintessential part of British society. Sipping on a warm cup of tea, alongside delicate finger sandwiches and freshly baked scones topped with clotted cream and jam, is a favourite pastime for many Brits. Whether in the elegant tearooms of London or a quaint village café, afternoon tea is a must-try experience for visitors.

Speaking of London, the capital city is a must-see for anyone visiting the UK. Home to iconic landmarks such as Buckingham Palace, Big Ben, and the London Eye, this bustling metropolis offers a mix of modernity and history. Take a stroll through the cobbled streets of Covent Garden, indulge in some retail therapy along Oxford Street, or catch a theatre show in the famous West End. London truly has something for everyone.

For those seeking a taste of British heritage, a trip to the countryside is a must. With its rolling green hills, charming villages, and ancient castles, the British countryside is a sight to behold. Visit the picturesque Cotswolds and wander through the quaint towns and villages that inspired countless works of literature. Or head up north to the Scottish highlands, where you can explore the rugged landscapes and visit historic sites such as the Edinburgh Castle.

No article on the UK would be complete without mentioning its vibrant music scene. From popular genres such as rock and pop to traditional folk music, the UK has produced some of the most influential musicians in the world. Take a stroll down Liverpool's famous Mathew Street, known as the birthplace of The Beatles, or catch a live performance at one of London's many music venues. Music lovers are sure to find their groove in the UK.

In addition to its cultural offerings, the UK is also a hub for academic excellence. Home to some of the world's most prestigious universities, including Oxford and Cambridge, the UK has a reputation for providing top-quality education. With a diverse range of degree programs and a rich learning environment, students from all over the world flock to the UK to pursue their academic dreams.

In conclusion, the United Kingdom has so much to offer visitors, from its charming traditions and stunning landscapes to its vibrant culture and academic opportunities. So why not plan a trip to this fascinating country and experience all that it has to offer? With its unique blend of old-world charm and modernity, the UK is a destination that should not be missed.

news.title: Leveraging artificial intelligence for vaccine development: A Ragon-MIT advancement in T cell epitope prediction

collectionItem.title: Leveraging artificial intelligence for vaccine development: A Ragon-MIT advancement in T cell epitope prediction

data.summary:
The MIT Jameel Clinic, in collaboration with the Ragon Institute, has published research in Nature Machine Intelligence introducing MUNIS, an AI tool that can accelerate the development of T cell vaccine candidates.

In tests using experimental data from influenza, HIV and Epstein-Barr virus, MUNIS significantly outperformed existing epitope prediction models, laying the foundation for applications in cancer T cell immunotherapy and autoimmunity research.

Regina Barzilay (MIT Jameel Clinic) commented on the breakthrough: “Through this collaboration with Dr Gaiha and his team, we learned a lot about this fascinating field and are excited about the immense possibilities in using AI algorithms to model the intricacies of the immune system."

news.title: Study in India shows kids use different math skills at work vs. school

collectionItem.title: Study in India shows kids use different math skills at work vs. school

data.summary:
A new J-PAL study in India shows that children who work in retail and those in school have contrasting mathematical abilities, reports MIT News.

Across three experiments, Esther Duflo noted: “For the school kids, they do worse when you go from an abstract problem to a concrete problem, for the market kids, it’s the opposite.”

news.title: "Revolutionizing Vaccine Development through AI: A Collaboration between Ragon Institute and MIT"

collectionItem.title: "Revolutionizing Vaccine Development through AI: A Collaboration between Ragon Institute and MIT"

data.summary:
Innovative Collaboration between Ragon Institute and MIT Leads to Major Breakthrough in Vaccine Development

An exciting partnership between the Ragon Institute and the Jameel Clinic at MIT has achieved a significant milestone in the development of T cell vaccines. This groundbreaking collaboration, led by Ragon faculty member Gaurav Gaiha, MD, DPhil, and MIT Professor Regina Barzilay, PhD, has resulted in the creation of MUNIS, a deep learning tool that can predict CD8+ T cell epitopes with unprecedented accuracy.

This achievement has the potential to greatly accelerate the development of vaccines against a wide range of infectious diseases. The project, which marks the first outcome of the Mark and Lisa Schwartz AI/ML Initiative at the Ragon Institute, was made possible through the generous support of Ragon Institute Board Chair Mark Schwartz and his wife, Lisa Schwartz.

By bringing together the expertise of the Gaiha Lab in T cell immunology and the Barzilay Lab in artificial intelligence, the team - led by co-first authors Jeremy Wohlwend, PhD, and Anusha Nathan, PhD - aimed to address a common challenge in vaccine development: the rapid and accurate identification of T cell epitopes in foreign pathogens.

Epitopes are specific regions of an antigen that are recognized by the body's immune cells and are crucial for activating targeted immune responses. Traditional methods for predicting epitopes are often time-consuming and inaccurate. With the integration of machine learning, however, researchers can now achieve faster and more efficient identification of these important immune targets.

Using a comprehensive dataset of over 650,000 unique human leukocyte antigen (HLA) ligands and state-of-the-art AI architectures, MUNIS outperformed existing epitope prediction models. The tool was validated using experimental data from influenza, HIV, and Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) and was able to identify novel immunogenic epitopes in EBV, a virus that has been extensively studied.

Remarkably, MUNIS achieved accuracy comparable to experimental stability assays, another form of epitope prediction. This demonstrates its potential to significantly reduce laboratory workloads and streamline vaccine design.

Professor Barzilay commented, "This is our first paper at the intersection of AI and immunology. Through this collaboration with Dr. Gaiha and his team, we have gained valuable insights into this fascinating field and are excited about the immense possibilities of using AI algorithms to model the complexities of the immune system."

One of the key factors in the development of MUNIS was the partnership between immunologists and computer scientists. This collaboration allowed for the fusion of their unique skills and expertise, ensuring the effectiveness of the tool in addressing complex biological challenges.

Dr. Gaiha added, "This is a wonderful application of artificial intelligence that greatly benefited from the shared insights of both computer scientists and immunologists. The credit goes to the initiative for bringing us together, which has resulted in the creation of

news.title: "Study Reveals Disparity in Math Skills Among Indian Children at Work and in School"

collectionItem.title: "Study Reveals Disparity in Math Skills Among Indian Children at Work and in School"

data.summary:
TITLE: Math Skills in Indian Children: The Struggle between Market and School

In India, children who work in markets exhibit impressive math skills. They are able to quickly perform a range of calculations in order to complete transactions. However, a new study has found that these children often struggle with the same types of math problems taught in the classroom. This is despite the fact that many of these children still attend school or have completed up to 7th or 8th grade.

The study, published in Nature, was co-authored by MIT economists Esther Duflo and Abhijit Banerjee, who shared the Nobel Prize in Economics in 2019. The research team also included members from Ananda Bazar Patrika newspaper, the Indian Institute of Management in Kolkata, New York University, and Harvard University.

The study consisted of three data-collection exercises and experiments. The first exercise involved 201 children working in markets in Kolkata, where researchers tested the children's math skills by posing as ordinary shoppers. They found that the children were able to correctly solve market-based math problems 95 to 98 percent of the time. However, when given a standardized Indian national math test, just 32 percent of the children were able to correctly answer division and subtraction problems.

A second study was conducted with 400 children working in markets in Delhi, which replicated the previous results. The researchers also added a new element by testing how well students who excel in school perform on market-based math problems. They found that while 96 percent of the students were able to solve problems with a pencil, paper, and unlimited time, only 60 percent were able to do so in a simulated market setting.

In a third study conducted in Delhi, the researchers compared the performance of market and school children on various math problems under different conditions. They found that while 85 percent of market children correctly answered market transaction problems, only 10 percent of school children were able to handle similar problems without the aid of a pencil and paper.

The results of these studies raise questions about how to effectively teach math to both market and school children. The researchers suggest that educational curricula should bridge the gap between intuitive and formal mathematics in order to help both groups of students learn more comprehensively.

Banerjee believes that part of the issue may be the strict curriculum and methods enforced in Indian schools. He suggests that teaching students to reason their way to an approximation of the correct answer, rather than focusing on a specific method, could be a better approach. The research team plans to continue their work in finding effective teaching strategies for Indian children.

The study was supported by the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab, the Foundation Blaise Pascal, and the AXA Research Fund. With further research and innovative teaching methods, it is hoped that Indian children will excel in both market and school-based math problems.

news.title: "Discovering New Talent: An Exciting Opportunity to Experience Opera at Clonter Opera Prize and Cast Your Vote!"

collectionItem.title: "Discovering New Talent: An Exciting Opportunity to Experience Opera at Clonter Opera Prize and Cast Your Vote!"

data.summary:
Clonter Opera Prize is an annual event that showcases the best of emerging talent in the opera world. Held at the prestigious Clonter Opera Theatre in Cheshire, this event is a must-see for opera enthusiasts and novices alike.

The contest is open to contestants nominated by the UK’s leading conservatoires, who compete for a prize before a distinguished panel of judges. But what sets this event apart is the unique role of the audience – they collectively act as one judge, and their vote is also revealed. This adds an extra level of excitement to the evening, as the audience gets to play an active role in determining the winner.

The event is perfect for anyone who is interested in spotting emerging talent and following the careers of young singers. It also provides a great opportunity for those new to opera to dip their toes into the operatic water, with a range of performances from different operas.

Each item is introduced and set into context by a compère and accompanied by world-class repetiteur Robin Humphreys, as described by critic Louise Flind in Opera Today. But that’s not all – audiences will also be treated to the customary appearance of Stephen Reynolds, playing his Clonter Fantasia. And to make sure guests don’t go hungry, the event includes the traditional 70-minute supper interval.

Sponsored by the Ann Driver Trust, Clonter Opera Prize has a long history of nurturing and promoting young talent in the opera world. With a strong belief in diversity and inclusivity, this event offers a platform for neglected talent due to various factors such as ethnicity, lack of access, socio-economic circumstances, and sexual orientation.

But it’s not just about the competition – this event also features renowned professionals in the opera world. David Gowland, the Artistic Director of the Jette Parker Artists Programme at the Royal Opera House, will be coaching artists from UK conservatoires. David, a jury member in numerous national and international competitions, has also conducted masterclasses and auditions in various countries such as China, South Korea, Australia, Brazil, and many more.

Joining him is Helen Sykes, a well-respected member of the Arts Administration world. With years of experience working with prestigious organizations such as English National Opera and London Philharmonic Orchestra, Helen now holds the position of Director at Groves Artists, a renowned artist management company.

The event also features Philip Sunderland, a graduate of the Royal Academy of Music and the National Opera Studio. Philip has an impressive background as a repetiteur and conductor, working with renowned opera companies such as English Touring Opera and Opera North. He is currently the Head of Preparatory and Vocal Faculty Opera at the Royal Academy of Music, and was previously the Chorus Master at the Bregenzer Festspiele.

news.title: ‘Transformative potential’: More arts funding on the horizon in Scotland following success of culture and health festival

collectionItem.title: ‘Transformative potential’: More arts funding on the horizon in Scotland following success of culture and health festival

data.summary:
The Scottish government’s chief medical officer Sir Gregor Smith celebrates the “transformative potential” of Healing Arts Scotland, a week-long celebration of the role of the arts for improving physical, mental and social health, produced by Scottish Ballet and the Jameel Arts & Health Lab in collaboration with the World Health Organisation in August 2024.

Sir Gregor told The Art Newspaper that the festival has shown how the arts can help to “reimagine our national model of health and social care.”

news.title: The week in classical: Opera triple bill: Britten, Weill and Ravel; Hänsel und Gretel; Tosca – review

collectionItem.title: The week in classical: Opera triple bill: Britten, Weill and Ravel; Hänsel und Gretel; Tosca – review

data.summary:
The Guardian celebrates Bocelli-Jameel scholar Anastasia Koorn as one of “the next generation of stars” in its review of the Royal College of Music’s triple-bill of Britten’s Les illuminations, Weill’s Chansons des quais and Ravel’s L’heure espagnole.

In her review, Fiona Maddocks refers to Anastasia’s performance as Concepción in L'heure espagnol as “starlet-like” in “an impressive cast.”

news.title: How research on people's networks in villages won Stanford prof Indy Prize

collectionItem.title: How research on people's networks in villages won Stanford prof Indy Prize

data.summary:
Arun Gautham Chandrasekhar (J-PAL) won the 2024 Infosys Prize for Economics for his work on the importance of “information ambassadors” within communities to spread knowledge of government schemes, reports The Times of India.

By identifying key members of communities to amplify messaging, Arun achieved a 44% increase in immunisation completion rates across seven districts.

news.title: 'The Traitors', a reality TV show, offers a useful economics lesson

collectionItem.title: 'The Traitors', a reality TV show, offers a useful economics lesson

data.summary: An Economist article on the popular reality TV show ‘The Traitors’ cites the ‘rational herding’ theory of Abhijit Banerjee (J-PAL) in considering strategies for victory: “Because behaviour provides information, and someone’s own information about the world is uncertain, it can be rational just to follow the crowd.”

news.title: MIT researchers introduce Boltz-1, a fully open-source model for predicting biomolecular structures

collectionItem.title: MIT researchers introduce Boltz-1, a fully open-source model for predicting biomolecular structures

data.summary:
The MIT Jameel Clinic unveils Boltz-1, the first commercially-available, open-source protein structure prediction model that achieves the same level of accuracy as AI-powered protein prediction model AlphaFold3.

In MIT News, Mathai Mammen, CEO and president of Parabilis Medicines, describes Boltz-1 as a “breakthrough” model: “By open-sourcing this advance, the MIT Jameel Clinic and collaborators are democratising access to cutting-edge structural biology tools.”

news.title: Early warning systems save lives but more funding is critical

collectionItem.title: Early warning systems save lives but more funding is critical

data.summary:
In light of estimates that 1.7 million people faced crisis levels of acute food security in Kenya between October 2024 and January 2025, Guyo Roba (Jameel Observatory) calls for more funding for extreme weather early warning systems and a more holistic approach in their implementation.

In an op-ed for Context, Guyo remarks that “current levels of investment are woefully inadequate,” and early warning systems often “fail to take into account local and traditional methods of communication.”

news.title: Experts forecast cancer research and treatment advances in 2025

collectionItem.title: Experts forecast cancer research and treatment advances in 2025

data.summary: Regina Barzilay shares her 2025 predictions for advances in cancer research and treatment with the American Association of Cancer Research: “I hope that 2025 will be the year where it changes and we are putting our efforts as clinicians, researchers and even as patients together and are lobbying for the use of AI technology in health care.”

news.title: Bird flu fight: 'A step along the road to panic taken'

collectionItem.title: Bird flu fight: 'A step along the road to panic taken'

data.summary:
Thomas Rawson shares with Food Navigator his reaction to the recent spread of bird flu (H5N1) from poultry to cows in the United States, and considers the potential risks of similar cases emerging among European livestock.

Thomas, who tracks the pathogen within commercial poultry flocks, argues that the most effective way of controlling its spread is by “keeping a good relationship between farms, government and the industry.”

news.title: AI in health should be regulated, but don’t forget about the algorithms, researchers say

collectionItem.title: AI in health should be regulated, but don’t forget about the algorithms, researchers say

data.summary:
In an interview with MIT News, Marzyeh Ghassemi comments on a recent ruling by the United States Office for Civil Rights preventing discrimination in the use of AI-powered tools for supporting clinicians taking decisions on patient care.

She remarks that the rule “should dictate equity-driven improvements to the non-AI algorithms and clinical decision-support tools already in use across clinical subspecialties.”

The MIT Jameel Clinic hosts a conference in March 2025 to address the lack of regulatory bodies overseeing AI-enabled clinical decision-support tools.

news.title: Economist Abhijit Banerjee: ‘Good storytellers are very powerful’

collectionItem.title: Economist Abhijit Banerjee: ‘Good storytellers are very powerful’

data.summary:
Abhijit Banerjee sits with the Financial Times to discuss the power of storytelling in economics, his childhood in West Bengal and founding the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab in 2003.

Over lunch, the FT’s John Reed remarks how Abhijit and J-PAL co-founder Esther Duflo “transformed their field by using randomised controlled trials to measure the impact of small interventions on policy outcomes for poor people.”

news.title: Integrating climate action into urban planning

collectionItem.title: Integrating climate action into urban planning

data.summary:
Cléa Daridan appears on the Urbanistica Podcast to discuss the work of the Jameel C40 Urban Planning Climate Labs in supporting cities to embed climate action into their strategies: “Understanding the community’s needs should be at the heart of how urban planners proceed and conceive cities, including when it comes to climate action.”

‍

news.title: Genetic clues explain why children develop rare post-COVID condition

collectionItem.title: Genetic clues explain why children develop rare post-COVID condition

data.summary: An Imperial College COVID-19 Excellence Fund-supported study reveals a gene which may explain why some children with mild COVID-19 go on to develop multisystem inflammatory syndrome (MIS-C): “Our new computational technique, which we call burdenMC, gives us the power to identify links between genes and diseases that were previously elusive. It is particularly useful for shedding light on small, diverse groups of patients with rare conditions such as MIS-C.”

news.title: Diabetes rate doubles to 800 million adults, but over half are untreated

collectionItem.title: Diabetes rate doubles to 800 million adults, but over half are untreated

data.summary: A study in The Lancet, led by Majid Ezzati at the Jameel Institute, reveals that the global diabetes rates have doubled since 1990 to more than 800 million adults: “Our study highlights widening global inequalities in diabetes, with treatment rates stagnating in many low- and middle-income countries where numbers of adults with diabetes are drastically increasing. This is especially concerning as people with diabetes tend to be younger in low-income countries and, in the absence of effective treatment, are at risk of life-long complications – including amputation, heart disease, kidney damage or vision loss – or in some cases, premature death.”

news.title: AI for social good

collectionItem.title: AI for social good

data.summary:
J-PAL executive director Iqbal Dhaliwal and senior policy associate Michael Hou call for rigorous impact evaluations of AI in the social sector in an article for the Stanford Social Innovation Review: “To inform our future decisions, we need to know what works and what doesn’t when we try to infuse our existing social programmes with a new general-purpose technology like AI or design new programmes based on it.

“Thanks to more than two decades of building the field of rigorous impact evaluations in partnership with implementers, donors and local communities, we can shape the direction of AI by learning from past evaluations and designing evidence-enhanced AI programmes from the start.”

news.title: Changemakers 2024: Pratham CEO Rukmini Banerji is a force for change

collectionItem.title: Changemakers 2024: Pratham CEO Rukmini Banerji is a force for change

data.summary:
Following the five year anniversary of Teaching at the Right Level (TaRL) Africa, a joint venture between J-PAL and Pratham International, Rukmini Banerji, CEO of Pratham Educational Foundation, is spotlighted by Outlook Business. In reference to the programme, which helps primary school children in 16 countries in sub-Saharan Africa acquire foundational learning skills, Rukmini says: “I feel deeply humbled and proud that something that we developed for our own needs has relevance and acceptance in other parts of the global South.”

‍

news.title: USAID launches new collaboration with leading evidence organisations to improve agency cost-effectiveness

collectionItem.title: USAID launches new collaboration with leading evidence organisations to improve agency cost-effectiveness

data.summary: USAID - the United States overseas aid agency - has announced an historic USD 75 million investment in J-PAL and 9 consortium partners (including the International Rescue Committee) to conduct rigorous evaluations of USAID’s global poverty reduction programmes. The consortium will “leverage a Nobel Prize-winning approach to guide the fight against global poverty” — referring to the 2019 Nobel prize awarded to J-PAL co-founders Esther Duflo and Abhijit Banerjee and their longtime collaborator Michael Kremer.

news.title: Esther Duflo: "I could never have won the Nobel Prize except at MIT"

collectionItem.title: Esther Duflo: "I could never have won the Nobel Prize except at MIT"

data.summary: In an interview with Les Echos, Esther Duflo reflects on J-PAL’s creation and the acceleration of its research thanks to the “decisive” support of Community Jameel’s chairman, Mohammed Jameel KBE: “Given the unfashionable nature of my early research, this support represented a real scientific risk [...] and proof of great open-mindedness.”

news.title: Cléa Daridan: Atelier Jameel’s vision of empowering artisans and showcasing traditional crafts

collectionItem.title: Cléa Daridan: Atelier Jameel’s vision of empowering artisans and showcasing traditional crafts

data.summary: Following the 2024 Atelier Jameel winter exhibition in Cairo, Cléa Daridan talks to Caravel about Atelier Jameel’s mission to sustain traditional arts: “Through the Jameel Houses in Cairo, Jeddah and Scotland, Community Jameel is committed to reinvigorating traditional Islamic arts otherwise at risk of loss. In turn, alumni move on to contribute to the practice, teaching and research around traditional arts, leading to artistic and personal growth. Many of them are now part of Atelier Jameel.”

In an article on MIT News, Mathai Mammen, CEO and president of Parabilis Medicines, describes Boltz-1 as a “breakthrough” model: “By open-sourcing this advance, the MIT Jameel Clinic and collaborators are democratising access to cutting-edge structural biology tools.”

Professor Elfatih Eltahir explains that the work was inspired by the realisation that “people’s understanding of climate change is based on the assumption that climate change is something that’s going to happen sometime in the future and going to happen to someone else. It’s not going to impact them directly. And I think that contributes to the fact that we are not doing enough.”

news.title: ‘We need a shared language’: Scotland-wide festival highlights links between the arts and health

collectionItem.title: ‘We need a shared language’: Scotland-wide festival highlights links between the arts and health

data.summary:
The Jameel Arts & Health Lab and the Scottish Ballet host the first national festival exploring the cultural engagement in health, aiming to unlock new funding streams for the arts in Scotland, reports The Art Newspaper.

Part of a global Healing Arts campaign created by the Jameel Arts & Health Lab in collaboration with the World Health Organisation, the week-long event is the first to involve over 100 activities happening in locations across a nation.

Nils Fietje, co-founding director of the Jameel Arts & Health Lab, tells The Art Newspaper: “One of the big challenges is that these are two sectors [healthcare and the arts] that don’t traditionally work together. We generally talk about how health intersects with transport, economics or education, but we haven’t explored it in the cultural sector. That’s because there aren’t many connections between these two fields, we don’t have a shared language. Bringing these worlds together is what this week is about.”

Launched in 2023, the Jameel Arts & Health Lab is a collaboration between the World Health Organisation (WHO) Regional Office for Europe, the Steinhardt School at New York University (NYU), Community Jameel and CULTURUNNERS to coordinate and amplify scientific research into the effectiveness of the arts in improving health and wellbeing.

news.title: [DO NOT PUBLISH] Ministry of Rural Development partners with J-PAL South Asia as it expands ‘Samaveshi Aajeevika’ across India

collectionItem.title: [DO NOT PUBLISH] Ministry of Rural Development partners with J-PAL South Asia as it expands ‘Samaveshi Aajeevika’ across India

data.summary:
India's Ministry of Rural Development is partnering with Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL)'s South Asia office to adopt the livelihood programme, 'Samaveshi aajeevika', aimed at rural women enhancing their financial self-sufficiency. As part of the partnership, J-PAL South Asia will also support the Ministry in adopting scientific evidence and data in their decision-making as it expands 'Samaveshi aajeevika' across India, reports Business News This Week.

The programme adapts Indian NGO BRAC’s 'Graduation approach', a comprehensive livelihoods programme that has been found effective at lifting the poorest of the poor households out of extreme poverty, in randomised evaluations run by J-PAL and Innovations For Poverty Action.

Shobhini Mukerji, executive director of J-PAL South Asia, says: “Graduation Approach is a big boost to Government of India’s vision for women-led development. The Ministry of Rural Development has shown phenomenal leadership in embracing scientific evidence and data in their decision-making. Samaveshi aajeevika is a powerful reminder that a robust ecosystem of governments, academic institutions and civil society organisations is vital to drive impact at scale.”

data.summary:
The Jameel Arts & Health Lab and the Scottish Ballet prepare to launch Healing Arts Scotland, a week-long, nationwide event advocating for the impact of arts on health, highlights Edinburgh Magazine. Part of a global Healing Arts campaign created by the Jameel Arts & Health Lab in collaboration with the World Health Organisation, events commence with the Healing Arts Scotland Conference in Edinburgh, followed by special activities across the country including 'Cancer tapestry,' featuring 100 cancer stories from around Scotland; a wellbeing concert in Glasgow; and 'Storywalk,' in the Cairngorms.

Christopher Bailey, founding co-director of the Jameel Arts & Health Lab and the arts and health lead at the World Health Organisation (WHO), says: “Many cities around the world have taken part in our series of healing arts activations, but I am excited to see Scotland taking a truly national approach. Scotland's unique sense of community, its embrace of all art forms, and its commitment to health for all promise to be an exciting combination. I can't wait to participate and see what the communities come up with."

news.title: Groundbreaking poverty alleviation project expands with new Arnold Ventures, J-PAL North America collaboration

collectionItem.title: Groundbreaking poverty alleviation project expands with new Arnold Ventures, J-PAL North America collaboration

data.summary:
The Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) North America regional office is set to significantly expand its work as a result of a new grant from long-time collaborator and supporter, Arnold Ventures. According to MIT News, the eight-figure, seven-year grant enables J-PAL North America to expand its base of rigorous evidence in effective poverty alleviation solutions, increase capacity and diversity amongst its network of researchers and accelerate the use of evidence towards policy and programming by policymakers and nonprofit organisations.

Vincent Quan, co-executive director of J-PAL North America, says: “J-PAL’s mission is to reduce poverty by ensuring that policy is informed by scientific evidence. We recognise that poverty is a pressing and complex issue, so we work to identify and scale solutions across various sectors, including education, health and labour. This support from Arnold Ventures will take our work to the next level, creating new pathways for generating evidence, informing policy and impacting lives. We are thrilled about this groundbreaking, expanded collaboration with Arnold Ventures on strengthening the evidence-informed ecosystem as we enter J-PAL North America’s second decade.”

news.title: MIT Jameel World Education Lab grants inaugural Frontiers in Digital Learning awards

collectionItem.title: MIT Jameel World Education Lab grants inaugural Frontiers in Digital Learning awards

data.summary:
The Abdul Latif Jameel World Education Lab (J-WEL) announces the recipients of the first Frontiers in Digital learning awards, and extension of the lab's Education Innovation grants. The new programme is designed to use insights from MIT Open Learning's Digital Learning Lab (DLL) to advance digital learning around the world.

John Harrold, MIT Department of Materials Science and Engineering (DMSE) instructor and DLL fellow, Jessica Sandland, DMSE principal lecturer and DLL scientist and Mary Ellen Wiltrout, MIT department of biology lecturer and DLL scientist are the recipients of the inaugural awards.

Anjali Sastry, faculty director for J-WEL, says: "We have long wanted to bring the incredibly varied and innovative work of the MIT Digital Learning Lab to many. The Frontiers in Digital Learning awards will pave the way, and, at the same time, directly support awardees. Our goal is to strengthen knowledge of the design, implementation, applicability and impact of digital learning innovation at MIT and across the world. Instructors and leaders in J-WEL’s network are eager to learn about field-tested insights and to launch their own tests and experimentation. We’re particularly excited about the opportunity to amplify and extend the work of these DLL grantees by facilitating collaborative implementation projects with a number of member institutions in the fall. Such small-scale efforts could reveal new insights about challenges and opportunities in digital learning that could apply everywhere—including on the MIT campus."

news.title: AI model identifies certain breast tumour stages likely to progress to invasive cancer

collectionItem.title: AI model identifies certain breast tumour stages likely to progress to invasive cancer

data.summary:
MIT News reports that research supported in part by the MIT Jameel Clinic, leads a team from MIT and ETH Zurich to develop an AI model for identifying different stages of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), a form of breast cancer that accounts for 25% of all breast cancer diagnoses, and can progress into an aggressive form of cancer, but whose stages are difficult for physicians to determine. The research identified the importance of not only the state, but also the arrangement of cells, which can be examined via inexpensive tissue images, enabling the the team to build an extensive dataset to train and test the model with promising results.

Caroline Uhler, a principal investigator at MIT Jameel Clinic, tells MIT News: "We took the first step in understanding that we should be looking at the spatial organisation of cells when diagnosing DCIS, and now we have developed a technique that is scalable. From here, we really need a prospective study. Working with a hospital and getting this all the way to the clinic will be an important step forward.”
data.arabicTitle: نموذج الذكاء الاصطناعي يحدد مراحل معينة من أورام الثدي التي من المرجح أن تتطور إلى سرطان غازي

news.title: Pioneering the future of materials extraction

collectionItem.title: Pioneering the future of materials extraction

data.summary:
Abdul Latif Jameel Water and Food Systems Lab (J-WAFS) Solutions Programme-supported spinout SiTration is poised to disrupt multiple industries with its novel materials extraction process. MIT News speaks with the startup's co-founders, Jeffrey Grossman and Brendan Smith, about the applications and implications of their breakthrough technology - a silicon membrane capable of extracting and recovering various critical materials - and their journey from research to commercialisation, following a seed funding round led by venture capital firm 2150, which raised USD 11.8 million.

Brendan explains the technology's application across manufacturing and clean energy industries, telling MIT News: "We can produce membranes with pore sizes from the molecular scale up to the size of a human hair in diameter, and everything in between. Combined with the ability to electrify the membrane and separate based on a material’s electrochemical properties, this tunability allows us to target a vast array of different operations and separation applications across industrial fields."

On his role in the startup, he adds: "What’s most fun to me about being a CEO of an early-stage startup is that there are 100 different factors, most people-oriented, that you have to navigate every day. Each stakeholder has different motivations and objectives. And you basically try to fit that all together, to create value for our partners and customers, the company and for society. You start with just an idea, and you have to keep leveraging that to form a more and more tangible product, to multiply and progress commercial relationships, and do it all at an ever-expanding scale."
data.arabicTitle: ريادة مستقبل استخراج المواد

“Having government programmes just for refugees may spark resentment,” Hanna said. “Citizens often have concerns about providing transfers to refugees rather than citizens, who may also be in need. Understanding the politics and how to make the programs have wider-spread support will be key for their scale-up.”

collectionItem.title: La ministra Saiz y el Nobel de Economía, Abhijit Banerjee, presentan los resultados del Laboratorio de Políticas de Inclusión

data.summary:
Co-founder and co-director of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab, Abhijit Banerjee, and Elma Saiz, the Spanish Minister of Inclusion, Social Security and Migration, discussed the results of the Ministry's Inclusion Policy Lab in a panel event titled 'The Inclusion Policy Laboratory: The scientific evidence at the service of people.' The conversation focused on the results of a pilot programme of randomised evaluations launched by the Ministry in order to understand how to improve inclusion policies.  

In his analysis of the pilot, Abhijit highlighted the importance of a minimum income to address poverty and exclusion, and stated that “it is essential to work on accessibility so that the Minimum Vital Income (IMV) application process is as easy as possible, and that Spain has the necessary knowledge to continue doing what needs to be done in the fight against poverty.”

news.title: The time is now: Harnessing rigorous evaluation in a post-ARPA America

collectionItem.title: The time is now: Harnessing rigorous evaluation in a post-ARPA America

data.summary:
Louise Geraghty, government partnerships lead at the Adbul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) North America, writes an op-ed published in Route Fifty urging cities and states to use federal funding provided under the 2021 American Rescue Plan Act (ARPA) before the spending deadline in 2026 to evaluate the effectiveness of new programmes, and to enhance their own evaluation capacity at the same time.

"When government leaders embed evaluation within their work to foster equity and economic mobility, they’re investing in building knowledge on how to best support their communities. This work is not easy. States and localities should make the most of the historic opportunity to devote ARPA funding—as well as future federal funding—to evaluation. This investment will help them sustain their programs and ensure they are best positioned to support the communities they serve for the long term," writes Louise.

news.title: Deaths at Saudi haj show challenge of shielding pilgrims from lethal climate

collectionItem.title: Deaths at Saudi haj show challenge of shielding pilgrims from lethal climate

data.summary:
Elfatih Eltahir, co-director of the Jameel Observatory and project lead of the Jameel Observatory Climate Resilience Early Warning Systems Network (CREWSnet), is cited in a Reuters article concerning the death of hundreds of pilgrims amid soaring temperatures at this year's haj in Saudi Arabia. Almost two million pilgrims travelled to Mecca in 2024 to perform haj rites. Heat-related deaths are not uncommon, but climate change has made the risks increasingly potent.

"It's a situation that is only getting worse with time," said Elfatih Eltahir, who published a paper on the dangers of heat stress for pilgrims in 2019.

news.title: The risk from H5N1 has never been greater – but making our farms bio-secure is harder than it seems

collectionItem.title: The risk from H5N1 has never been greater – but making our farms bio-secure is harder than it seems

data.summary:
Thomas Rawson, epidemiology research associate, Jameel Institute at Imperial College London, authors an op-ed for The Telegraph on the risk of H5N1 bird flu, which has recently been reported to infect cows. He discusses the limitations of biosecurity measures and other methods of reducing the risks of spread and spillover – calling for more rigorous use of data to investigate how infections move through poultry populations.

Thomas writes: 'While bacteria like Campylobacter are sadly widespread throughout the system, it does mean we can use this organism to begin this work immediately without having to wait for more bird flu outbreaks. Next then is to understand how wild bird populations move and interact throughout the UK to help build better predictive maps of where outbreaks are likely to occur, so we know where and when we may have to be extra vigilant. Research on this currently is severely lacking.'

news.title: Early warning systems eliminate hunger - so why the lack of investment?

collectionItem.title: Early warning systems eliminate hunger - so why the lack of investment?

data.summary:
‍Nader Diab, Head of Programmes at Community Jameel, wrote an op-ed for AgTechNavigator discussing early warning systems for extreme weather events and the work of the Jameel Observatory for Food Security Early Action, based at the International Livestock Research Institute (ILRI) in Nairobi, Kenya, which addresses the compound threats exacerbated by climate shocks in the drylands of East Africa through early warning systems and anticipatory action.

Nader speaks to the advancements in climate modelling technology, data generation, and local stakeholder engagement that enable early warning systems to mitigate the risks of hunger crises resulting from droughts and other extreme weather events, and argues for greater international financing towards anticipatory action.

He writes: "Despite the technology, despite the prioritisation from global authorities, and despite the promise of a solution, investment isn't coming. Soliciting the support of governments or individual investors remains a challenge. Potential investors are more inclined to give during emergencies, as these elicit an emotional response, even if money spent ahead of time is more effective."

"This is a challenge that demands those able to invest change their perspective. A simple shift in how we view investment priorities has the potential to save lives, protect incomes, and enhance the quality of life for more than half the world's population."

news.title: MIT-Takeda Program wraps up with 16 publications, a patent, and nearly two dozen projects completed

collectionItem.title: MIT-Takeda Program wraps up with 16 publications, a patent, and nearly two dozen projects completed

data.summary:
MIT News, as part of the coverage of MIT's School of Engineering, features the MIT-Takeda Programme, an MIT Jameel Clinic powered initiative, that is now drawing to a close having produced multiple joint research papers, discoveries and a patent for a system that could improve the manufacturing of small-molecule medicines.

Launched in February 2020, the programme is a collaboration between Takeda Pharmaceutical Company Limited and MIT's school of engineering, and focused on leveraging both organisations' expertise to explore AI in healthcare and drug development. During its operation, MIT researchers and Takeda employees collaborated on 22 projects tackling drug development challenges and more than 150 Takeda researchers and staff participated in educational programming organised by the MIT Jameel Clinic.

A second element of the programme that will continue is the MIT-Takeda Fellowship, which supports graduate students as they pursue groundbreaking research related to health and AI and has supported 44 MIT-Takeda fellows to date.

news.title: Say hello to your addiction risk score — courtesy of the tech industry

collectionItem.title: Say hello to your addiction risk score — courtesy of the tech industry

data.summary:
Marzyeh Ghassemi, a 2023-2024 MIT Jameel Clinic principal investigator, is quoted by the New York Times on the topic of genetic tests designed to predict the risk of opioid addiction. According to the article, several studies have found that some of these tests could mislabel individuals who are descended from two or more racial groups as being at high risk of addiction. Since most African Americans have such admixed ancestry, this could bias the test into identifying them as high risk.

“This means that the model can use the genetic markers of African American status to predict opioid use disorder, instead of using any biologically plausible genetic markers,” said Marzyeh.

news.title: Better cardiovascular care through AI

collectionItem.title: Better cardiovascular care through AI

data.summary:
Collin Stultz, a 2023-2024 MIT Jameel Clinic principal investigator, tells MIT Spectrum in their Spring 2024 issue about how patients with heart disease can be helped by applying machine learning techniques to cardiovascular medicine.

"Machine learning will bring more equitable and fairer care for everyone,” he says. “What we want to do, at a high level, is move the hospital to the home setting. If we can help each patient, regardless of their background or where they reside, get the same level of care that a patient at a tertiary care centre like MGH receives, then we will be closer to realising excellent and unbiased care for all patients with cardiovascular disease.”

news.title: How a quantum scientist, a nurse, and an economist are joining the fight against global poverty

collectionItem.title: How a quantum scientist, a nurse, and an economist are joining the fight against global poverty

data.summary:
MIT's MicroMasters in Data, Economics, and Design of Policy (DEDP), jointly led by the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) and MIT Open Learning, equips students from diverse educational and professional backgrounds with the data science skills necessary to build a new career in combating global poverty.

A recent graduate from the programme, Sofia Martinez Galvez, who is a former quantum scientist and now the co-founder of a nonprofit focused on tackling education in sub-Saharan Africa, told MIT News about the programme, “If someone told me a few years ago, when I was doing research in quantum physics, that I would be starting my own organisation at the intersection of education and poverty, I would have said they were crazy. From my first MicroMasters course, I knew I made the right choice. The instructors used mathematics, models and data to understand society.”
