news.title: Jameel Observatory early warning system showcased by US and UAE governments at climate change summit in Washington, DC

collectionItem.title: Jameel Observatory early warning system showcased by US and UAE governments at climate change summit in Washington, DC

data.summary: The Jameel Observatory Climate Resilience Early Warning System Network (Jameel Observatory-CREWSnet), a new project launched by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) and Community Jameel, has been selected as an innovation sprint at the 2023 summit of the Agriculture Innovation Mission for Climate (AIM4C). AIM4C is a joint initiative of the United States and United Arab Emirates that seeks to enhance climate action by accelerating agriculture and food systems innovation and investment. Piloted initially in Bangladesh in partnership with BRAC, the Jameel Observatory-CREWSnet platform combines climate and socioeconomic forecasting techniques with technological solutions to empower communities worldwide to adapt to climate shocks.

collectionItem.title: Royal College of Music musicians take part in Westminster Abbey service and Windsor Castle coronation concert

data.summary: The coronation concert held on Sunday, 7 May 2023, brings together global music icons, contemporary stars and alumni and affiliates of the Royal College of Music (RCM) in celebration of crowning of King Charles III. The line-up included bass-baritone Sir Bryn Terfel and tenor Andrea Bocelli, whose foundation supports the RCM through the Andrea Bocelli Foundation-Community Jameel scholarship. Launched in 2019, the scholarship supports a talented musician to study at RCM's renowned opera studio each year.

data.summary: The Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) Europe office named Uzbekistan its 'country of the month' for May, in recognition of the nation's progress in developing comprehensive policies to overcome poverty and improve social protection in recent years. In May 2022, J-PAL, which was co-founded by Nobel Prize for Economics winners Abhijit Banerjee and Esther Duflo, together with the Centre for Economic Research and Reforms, organised a seminar in cooperation with the Uzbekistan government to assist in the development and testing of innovative approaches to improve state programmes designed to combat poverty.

news.title: Eight MIT faculty elected to American Academy of Arts and Sciences for 2023

collectionItem.title: Eight MIT faculty elected to American Academy of Arts and Sciences for 2023

data.summary: Eight Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) faculty members are among more than 250 leaders from academia, the arts, industry, public policy and research elected to the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, one of the most prestigious honorary societies and a leading centre for independent policy research. Among those elected is Evelyn Wang, principal investigator (2017, 2021) at the Abdul Latif Jameel Water and Food Systems Lab (J-WAFS) and head of MIT's department of mechanical engineering. In 2022, Evelyn was appointed the director of the US department of energy’s 'Advanced research projects agency-energy' to support critical energy research.

news.title: How childcare empowers women

collectionItem.title: How childcare empowers women

data.summary: Providing access to childcare can help women achieve greater economic parity and enhance their agency, and could also lead to a substantial boost to the global economy. Selim Gulesci, associate professor of economics at Trinity College Dublin and affiliate of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) joins VoxDevTalks to discuss recent research on how childcare can empower women in developing countries. Selim's research is centred on development economics, labor and gender.

news.title: Abhijit Banerjee talks to Madhur Jaffrey about the subtleties of South Asian cooking

collectionItem.title: Abhijit Banerjee talks to Madhur Jaffrey about the subtleties of South Asian cooking

data.summary: For the Mittal Institute's Harish C Mahindra lecture this year, Indian-American actress Madhur Jaffrey shared stories from her upbringing in British India, her acting career and how she became an icon of South Asian cooking globally. Jaffrey was then interviewed by Abhijit Banerjee, co-founder and co-director of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) and publisher of his own cookbook, 'Cooking to save your life', who asked her what she believes should be India's national dish. 'We’re too diverse a nation to have any one dish', she quipped.

news.title: IKEA Foundation commits USD 10 million to IPA and J-PAL to study refugee work programmes

collectionItem.title: IKEA Foundation commits USD 10 million to IPA and J-PAL to study refugee work programmes

data.summary: Innovations for Poverty Action (IPA) and the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) have announced a five-year, USD 10 million grant from the IKEA Foundation in support of research on the effectiveness of livelihood programmes for refugee and displaced populations and their host communities. Part of J-PAL's Displaced Livelihoods Initiative, the fund is the first of its kind and will help IPA and J-PAL generate data to inform policy makers and practitioners as they design evidence-based policies and programmes that aim to support displaced people to create sustainable livelihoods and achieve self-reliance.

news.title: Why AI is set to become an important healthcare tool, not a threat

collectionItem.title: Why AI is set to become an important healthcare tool, not a threat

data.summary: Despite concerns that doctors will become a relic of the past, AI is not a threat but an component in the future of health care. One key source of optimism is the work of AI Faculty Lead at the MIT Jameel Clinic, Regina Barzilay, who built an AI algorithm called Mirai, which improves the analysis of mammograms and detection of potentially cancerous cells among women. Mirai is currently undergoing trials at eight locations around the world, testing around 200,000 women.

news.title: CREWSnet project forecasts a climate early warning system for all

collectionItem.title: CREWSnet project forecasts a climate early warning system for all

data.summary: One of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) Climate Grand Challenges flagship projects, the Jameel Observatory Climate Resilience Early Warning System Network (Jameel Observatory-CREWSnet) is a forecasting platform which aims to empower underserved communities by providing tools they need to adapt to climate shocks and plan for the future. Launched by MIT and Community Jameel in partnership with Bangladesh-based partner BRAC and the Agricultural Research Corporation-Sudan, the platform will pilot initially in Bangladesh and Sudan with a view to expanding support to climate-vulnerable communities worldwide, especially in the agricultural sector. The project is led by Professor Elfatih Eltahir, co-director of the Jameel Observatory, an international research laboratory that uses data and technology to help communities adapt to climate change impacts.

collectionItem.title: National Academy of Sciences elects Jameel Clinic PI Dina Katabi

data.summary: Established by an Act of Congress and signed by President Abraham Lincoln in 1863, the National Academy of Sciences (NAS) recognises outstanding and original contributions to research. Today, the NAS announced the election of 120 members and 23 international members including Dina Katabi, principal investigator at the MIT Jameel Clinic, the epicentre of artificial intelligence (AI) and healthcare at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT). Dina was recognised for her outstanding research on wireless systems and AI, which have had a significant impact on the field.

news.title: Scientists: Climate change made eastern Africa drought worse

collectionItem.title: Scientists: Climate change made eastern Africa drought worse

data.summary:
The ongoing drought in eastern Africa has been made worse by human-induced climate change, which also made it much likelier to occur in the first place, an international team of climate scientists, including Guyo Malicha Roba, head of the Jameel Observatory, has concluded. The report was published by the World Weather Attribution, a group that seeks to quickly determine whether certain extreme weather events were influenced by climate change.

news.title: New Displaced Livelihoods Initiative will help advance sustainable livelihoods for displaced and host communities

collectionItem.title: New Displaced Livelihoods Initiative will help advance sustainable livelihoods for displaced and host communities

data.summary: Today, over 100 million people have been forcibly displaced to escape violence, conflict, or persecution. Projected to continue growing, displacement is also intertwined with poverty, food insecurity and climate change. The newly-launched Displaced Livelihoods Initiative (DLI), which will be jointly managed by Innovations for Poverty Action (IPA) and the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL), with generous support from the IKEA Foundation, is the world’s first research fund dedicated to generating rigorous experimental and quasi-experimental evidence to inform policies and programmes that can foster sustainable livelihoods for displaced and host communities.

news.title: East Africa drought worsened by climate change

collectionItem.title: East Africa drought worsened by climate change

data.summary:
An international team of climate scientists, including Guyo Roba, head of the Jameel Observatory, announced that the ongoing drought in eastern Africa has been made worse by human-induced climate change, in a report from World Weather Attribution. The United Nations said more than 20 million people in Kenya, Ethiopia, Somalia, Uganda and South Sudan have been affected by the drought, with more than 2.2 million displaced in Somalia and Ethiopia.

news.title: Scientists: Climate change worsened eastern Africa drought

collectionItem.title: Scientists: Climate change worsened eastern Africa drought

data.summary: The ongoing drought in eastern Africa has been made worse by human-induced climate change, which also made it much likelier to occur in the first place, an international team of climate scientists concluded. According to Guyo Malicha Roba, head of the Jameel Observatory, the food situation in the region’s drylands has been addressed by raising money and with food distributions from governments and humanitarian partners, but more work needs to be done to use early warning systems to respond more quickly to food shocks.

news.title: Tamil Nadu government did not consult economic advisory council before it amended Factories Act: Jean Drèze

collectionItem.title: Tamil Nadu government did not consult economic advisory council before it amended Factories Act: Jean Drèze

data.summary: The economic advisory council of the Tamil Nadu government, which boasts the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) co-founder and co-director, Esther Duflo, former Reserve Bank of India (RBI) governor Raghuram Rajan and development economist Jean Drèze, among others, was established to advise Chief Minister Stalin on economic matters concerning the Indian state of Tamil Nandu. On 24 April, Stalin halted further action on the Factories (Tamil Nandu Amendment) Act 2023, which aimed at flexible work hours in factories. Drèze hoped that the Tamil Nandu government will defend the amendment, warning that in its current form, it would jeopardise women's labour rights in particular.

news.title: Going digital makes aid programmes more effective

collectionItem.title: Going digital makes aid programmes more effective

data.summary:
Starting about five years ago, the Indonesian government stopped sending 10-kilogram bags of rice to villages and began sending debit cards instead so people could buy the food themselves. The result, according to a study led in part by Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) researchers, including J-PAL's co-founder and co-director, Abhijit Banerjee, was that people received all the food intended for them 81% of the time—as opposed to 24% previously. Under the old system, it’s likely that some was handed out to people not poor enough to be eligible. The cards eliminated this problem.

Determined to continue her studies and pursue her ambitions, Tahmina found the Massachusetts Institute of Technology Refugee Action Hub (MIT ReACT) and was accepted onto its certificate in computer science and data science programme in 2022. MIT ReACT provides education and professional opportunities to learners from refugee and forcibly displaced communities worldwide.

news.title: Delaying second COVID-19 jab ‘saved thousands of lives’

collectionItem.title: Delaying second COVID-19 jab ‘saved thousands of lives’

data.summary: The decision in early 2021 to delay people’s second COVID-19 jabs caused huge controversy in the United Kingdom, but research has now found that this saved thousands of lives, according to a retrospective analysis from researchers at the Jameel Institute at Imperial College London. The study, authored by director of the Jameel Institute, Neil Ferguson, and epidemiologist, Anne Cori, among others, aimed to quantify the impact of delaying the delivery of second vaccine doses on the epidemic in England and found that the delay may have prevented 58,000 hospital admissions and 10,000 deaths between 8 December 2020 and 13 September 2021.

The collaboration, entitled CLIMAVORE x Jameel at RCA, will allow Daniel Pascual Fernández and Alon Schwabe of Cooking Sections to focus on two large-scale projects analysing how climate change is affecting the food we eat and the way we grow it. news.title: A better way to make development projects work

collectionItem.title: A better way to make development projects work

data.summary: Gabriella Carolini, a principal investigator at the Abdul Latif Jameel Water and Food Systems Lab (J-WAFS) and associate professor of urban planning and international development at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, emphasises in her book that equitable partnership on the ground delivers the best results in the Global South. After years of field research in Mozambique, Carolini argues that the best development projects involve close cooperation between proximate peers: the sharing of information among partners, a consistent presence on the ground, non-hierarchical governance and a drive towards 'equity', in many forms, as a key project goal.

news.title: How an AI scientist turned her breast cancer diagnosis into a tool to save lives

collectionItem.title: How an AI scientist turned her breast cancer diagnosis into a tool to save lives

data.summary:
When, Professor Regina Barzilay, AI faculty lead at the MIT Jameel Clinic was first diagnosed with breast cancer in 2014, she began asking, why her cancer could not have been diagnosed earlier. Regina and fellow researchers at the MIT Jameel Clinic, the epicentre of AI and healthcare at MIT, developed an AI-based system for early detection of breast cancer called Mirai. The non-invasive technology has the potential has the ability to detect breast cancer up to five years in advance. Regina’s story is featured in a new FRONTLINE documentary, 'In the age of AI', that explores both the promise and the perils of AI.

news.title: Could AI be the key to detecting lung cancer years in advance?

collectionItem.title: Could AI be the key to detecting lung cancer years in advance?

data.summary:
A team of researchers at the Abdul Latif Jameel Clinic, the epicentre of AI and healthcare at MIT, have developed is a new AI tool called Sybil that can detect lung cancer risk up to years in advance. Much like the Greek oracles its named after, Sybil's job is to see into the future and has the potential to detect lung cancer—the leading cause of cancer death in the United States—years before doctors or radiologists can. According to Regina Barzilay, AI faculty lead at MIT Jameel Clinic and a researcher on the Sybil project, 'AI in health care is one of the most under-utilised areas of applications of AI'.

data.summary: Ahead of the announcement of the 2023 winner of the Nobel Prize in Economics, the 2019 winner of the prize, and co-founder of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab, Esther Duflo, comments on the recently promulgated pension reforms in France. In an article in La Tribune, Esther considers the pension reform 'regressive' and overly complicated, bearing adverse impact on the country's poorest pensioners. She also dissects the impact of hyperinflation on the poor and pleads for the creation of a special fund for low-income countries financed by an increase in the minimum global tax on companies currently set at 15%.

The 2019 Nobel Prize winner, Esther Duflo, and co-founder and co-director of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL), has stated that she sees nothing 'rational' in the pension plan in an article in La Tribune, asserting that 'this reform will make it possible to save money, but at the expense of the poorest'.

news.title: MIT PhD students honoured for their work to solve critical issues in water and food

collectionItem.title: MIT PhD students honoured for their work to solve critical issues in water and food

data.summary: Gokul Sampath and Jie Yun have been named 2023 Abdul Latif Jameel Water and Food Systems Lab (J-WAFS) fellows. Awarded to outstanding PhD students at MIT working on water and food-related challenges, both students were recognised for their 'passion to solve issues of agricultural sustainability and resilience and access to safe water', said J-WAFS executive director, Renee J Robins. A former research associate at the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab, where he conducted randomised control trials in India, Gokul's research focused on strategies to address the arsenic crisis in India and Bangladesh. Jie studies plant response to drought stress in the hopes of improving agricultural sustainability and yield under climate change. She is advised by David Des Marais and has collaborated with Caroline Uhler’s group in the department of electrical engineering and computer science to use computational tools to evaluate plant resilience and adaptation.

collectionItem.title: Could bird flu be the next COVID-19? Why experts are warning Britain of ‘sleepwalking’ into a new pandemic

data.summary: A woman in China has become the first person to die from a type of bird flu that is rare in humans. Some experts warn that the world could be 'sleepwalking' into a new pandemic. Professor Neil Ferguson, director of the Jameel Institute at Imperial College London, the researcher whose modelling was instrumental to informing policy during the COVID-19 pandemic, is said to be working on a COVID-style model for a bird flu pandemic following warnings from the World Health Organisation that it poses the biggest pandemic threat to the world after COVID-19. Neil's work on improving resilience in the face of future pandemic threats coincides with the aims of the Jameel Institute-Kenneth C Griffin Initiative for the Economics of Pandemic Preparedness, launched in 2022.

news.title: AI for drug development: How trustworthy is the tech?

collectionItem.title: AI for drug development: How trustworthy is the tech?

data.summary: The use of AI in drug development raises questions about the trustworthiness and transparency of the technology. That said, Jim Collins, principal investigator at the MIT Jameel Clinic, believes that AI can be a powerful tool in drug development in spite of its pitfalls. In 2020, Jim and a team of researchers discovered Halicin using AI, a new antibiotic which was effective at treating a range of bacteria, including some that are antibiotic-resistant. While the discovery of Halicin is a significant breakthrough, Collins recognises the need for greater collaboration between researchers, pharmaceutical companies and regulatory agencies to ensure that AI is used responsibly and effectively in drug development.

data.summary: Scientists from the MIT Jameel Clinic and Massachusetts General Hospital, including Jameel Clinic's AI faculty lead, Regina Barzilay, have developed a new AI tool which can detect the first symptoms of lung cancer even before they are noticeable on a CT scan. Named Sybil, in honour of the sibyls, who were prophetesses in Greek and Roman mythology, the first results of studies released last January indicated that the tool predicted whether a person could develop cancer over the course of a year with an accuracy of between 86% and 94%.

data.summary: For the past three decades, the gap between the rate of men and women's participation in the Indonesian labour force has remained stagnant (83.01% and 55.04% respectively, according to 2018 national bureau statistics). However, a more recent survey by the United Nations Development Program and the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) South-East Asia conducted across eight cities in Indonesia in 2021, finds that, on average, women work more hours doing non employment-related tasks. The survey reveals a higher proportion of women devote, on average, more than three hours per day of domestic labor compared to men, while a higher proportion of men devote, on average, more than two hours a day to domestic production.

news.title: WHO director general's opening remarks at WHO 75th anniversary concert at Victoria Hall

collectionItem.title: WHO director general's opening remarks at WHO 75th anniversary concert at Victoria Hall

data.summary: In his opening speech at a concert to mark the 75th anniversary of the World Health Organisation (WHO) in Geneva, Dr Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus remarked on the achievements of WHO since its founding in 1948 in the aftermath of World War II, including the eradication of diseases such as smallpox and polio and the formal recognition of health as a fundamental human right for all people. He also acknowledged the many challenges faced and those that are ongoing, which the COVID-19 pandemic demonstrated so powerfully. He closed by highlighting the power of the arts for health and wellbeing, and for building vibrant communities and societies, noting also the establishment of the Jameel Arts & Health Lab in this regard, WHO's first ever arts and health laboratory. Co-led by Christopher Bailey, the lab aims to amplify scientific research into the impacts of the arts on health and wellbeing to promote the integration of the arts into mainstream healthcare.

news.title: India's Bihar leads efforts to strengthen global poverty alleviation through South-South knowledge exchange

collectionItem.title: India's Bihar leads efforts to strengthen global poverty alleviation through South-South knowledge exchange

data.summary: Bihar, the largest state in terms of population in India, announced the launch of a new programme for immersion and learning exchange. The new programme will be launched under the Bihar Rural Livelihoods Promotion Society, known as JEEVIKA, which also implements Satat Jeevikoparjan Yojana (SJY), a government-led poverty alleviation programme in Bihar that has reached over 150,000 households as of 2023 and continues to expand. SJY aims to support people in extreme poverty and the most excluded households through the 'Graduation' approach, a model invented by BRAC in 2002, which is an evidence-based, multifaceted set of interventions that includes support of consumption, livelihoods, savings and training. A rigorous study of the 'Graduation' approach in West Bengal by co-founders and co-directors of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab, Abhijit Banerjee and Esther Duflo, demonstrates that 'Graduation' provides people with the resources and skills needed to break the poverty trap.

collectionItem.title: MIT Jameel World Education Lab welcomes three member organisations dedicated to helping aspiring innovators to start smart

data.summary: Three non-profit organisations with a proven record of local and regional support for emerging entrepreneurs are joining MIT's Jameel World Education Lab (J-WEL) network as its pilot innovation cohort. Member organisations benefit from J-WEL's curation of ideas, workshops, global linkage to like-minded educators, access to MIT resources, and collaboration, enabling them to better serve learners. Each new member is launching a programme under the heading of StartSmart, recognizing their expertise in their regions and prior collaborations with MIT. "StartSmart members are ready to inspire and equip entrepreneurially minded learners who will put what they learn to use within their communities. The careers they build, solutions they develop, and new businesses they create will benefit many," said Dr Anjali Sastry, faculty director of J-WEL.

collectionItem.title: Shobhaa De's book oscillates between the sombre and serious and is delightful in its description of everything Bengali

data.summary: Shobhaa De's memoir 'Insatiable: My hunger for life' offers reflections on mortality, everyday fears and vanities as the writer approached her 75th birthday. Written in the the shadow the COVID-19 pandemic, Shobhaa chronicles a year of attempting to bring together family and friends in diverse places, her pursuit of writing as well as the rituals and rhythms of literary and cultural festivities, and ties them all together with food. She offers anecdotes and portrayals of friends who share in similar passions, including Abhijit Banerjee, co-founder and co-director of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) and author of 'Cooking to save your life', a collection of home-cooking recipes interspersed with his economic insights.

news.title: Doctors are drowning in paperwork. Some companies claim AI can help

collectionItem.title: Doctors are drowning in paperwork. Some companies claim AI can help

data.summary: Start-up companies claim that new machine learning programmes similar to ChatGPT could complete doctors' paperwork for them. However, some experts are concerned that inherent bias and a tendency to fabricate facts could result in errors. Among them is Marzyeh Ghassemi, principal investigator at the MIT Jameel Clinic, the epicentre of AI and healthcare at MIT, who is worried that a rush to incorporate the latest AI technology into medicine could lead to errors and biased outcomes that may harm patients. "When you take state-of-the-art machine learning methods and systems and then evaluate them on different patient groups, they do not perform equally," Marzyeh said in an interview with NPR. "That's because these systems are trained on vast amounts of data generated by humans. And whether that data is from the internet or a medical study, it contains all the human biases that already exist in our society."

news.title: How can civil society contribute toward achieving water security?

Life From Water, an Egyptian non-profit organisation with branches in Germany and Canada established, has built partnerships with Egyptian civil society organisations to improve water access in Egypt's Fayoum, Assyut, Sohag and Qena communities. In order to achieve water security, Muhannad emphasised that policy makers need to realise the importance of inclusiveness, data sharing and cooperation between parties as well as the importance of measuring the impact of water policies and projects in the Arab world.

data.summary: Cooking and eating healthy food can have a positive impact on physical and mental health, and ultimately lead to a more successful life. But what is the importance of food and cooking in the lives of some of the world's leading thinkers? In this article, several Nobel laureates, including Abhijit Banerjee and Esther Duflo, co-founders and co-directors of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL), share their love for cooking and how it has influenced their lives and work to alleviate global poverty. Abhijit published his own cookbook in 2021, 'Cooking to save your life' which ties together economic lessons with his own recipes.
data.arabicTitle: عندما يدور العالم حول الطبخ والأكل: الأطعمة التي تغذي وترعى الحائزين على جائزة نوبل

news.title: Shobhaa De on why she chose to discuss food, not scandals, in her new memoir 'Insatiable'

collectionItem.title: Shobhaa De on why she chose to discuss food, not scandals, in her new memoir 'Insatiable'

data.summary: Indian writer Shobhaa De discusses the publication of her latest memoir 'Insatiable', a reflection on her food-filled life in the post-pandemic year 2022, as the writer turned 75. Rather than tell a linear tale of her celebrity life, Shobhaa decided to write a food memoir offering portraits of people and experiences from her past and present. The book includes anecdotes of dinners with family and notable friends such as the co-founders and co-directors of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) and Nobel laureates, Abhijit Banerjee and Esther Duflo.
data.arabicTitle: شبحة دي تتحدث عن سبب اختيارها لمناقشة الطعام وليس الفضائح في مذكراتها الجديدة "لا يشبع"

news.title: Tutoring works on paper, how about in practice?​

collectionItem.title: Tutoring works on paper, how about in practice?​

data.summary: Kim Dadisman, associate director of policy at the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) North America and Laina Sonterblum, senior policy associate at J-PAL North America, explore how tutoring programmes can be an effective tool in combatting learning loss and supplementing curriculums in schools in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic. In the United States, the Biden administration has publicly called on districts to spend COVID-relief dollars on tutoring. In the United Kingdom, the Department for Education launched the national tutoring programme. These initiatives are excellent steps toward learning recovery, but could fall short of their potential if implementation strays too far from the evidence. Evidence from rigorous evaluations of nearly 100 tutoring programmes demonstrated that tutoring consistently had large, positive impacts on student learning. That said, not all programmes are equally effective.
data.arabicTitle: الدروس الخصوصية تعمل على الورق ، ماذا عن الممارسة العملية؟

news.title: J-PAL North America and Results for America launch support for state and local leaders to evaluate programs using federal recovery dollars

collectionItem.title: J-PAL North America and Results for America launch support for state and local leaders to evaluate programs using federal recovery dollars

data.summary: A new program, titled Leveraging Evaluation and Evidence for Equitable Recovery (LEVER), has been launched by the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) North America and Results for America, a nonprofit focused on helping policymakers use data and evidence effectively. LEVER aims to assist state and local leaders in using evaluation and evidence in their decision-making as they seek to promote economic mobility and racial equity in the aftermath of COVID-19. Vincent Quan, Co-executive Director of J-PAL North America, highlighted the importance of evaluation and evidence in sustaining economic recovery, but acknowledged the challenges in implementing evidence-based policies. Both Results for America and J-PAL North America, as experienced organizations in evidence-based policymaking, are committed to supporting jurisdictions at their current level of readiness in this endeavor.

news.title: BAE Incubator partner series, part five: Seeking systems-level change to address housing instability

collectionItem.title: BAE Incubator partner series, part five: Seeking systems-level change to address housing instability

data.summary: Homelessness in the United States is a pressing issue that requires increased research on effective strategies to address it and foster long-term housing stability. With grant funding from Google.org—Google’s philanthropic arm—the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) North America's Bay Area Evaluation (BAE) Incubator supported Bay Area service providers with implementing and evaluating cash transfer programmes to assess their impact on homelessness and housing stability. J-PAL North America’s Evaluation Incubators build the base of rigorous evidence by supporting organizations and government agencies to transform their research questions into comprehensive evaluation designs. The model provides selected partners with funding, technical assistance and training on evaluation design, and connections to J-PAL’s network of expert researchers.

news.title: J-PAL at 20: Promoting more inclusive education in Italy

collectionItem.title: J-PAL at 20: Promoting more inclusive education in Italy

data.summary: How can we ensure that students from all backgrounds can achieve their academic potential? In the first of a series of blog posts exploring the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab's (J-PAL's) research and activities across Europe, Cillian Nolan, Director of policy at J-PAL Europe, looks at a series of randomised evaluations in Italy that explore this question with a particular focus on students from immigrant families. As school systems across Europe welcome increasingly diverse populations, this research provides insights into pathways for transforming students’ educational aspirations and academic performance, as well as their well-being.

news.title: Living in cities is not necessarily beneficial for growth of children, study finds

collectionItem.title: Living in cities is not necessarily beneficial for growth of children, study finds

data.summary: A global consortium of over 1,500 researchers and physicians, led by researchers at the Jameel Institute at Imperial College London, including principal investigator, Majid Ezzati, analysed the height and weight data of 71 million children and adolescents aged 5 to 19 years across urban and rural areas in 200 countries. Between 1990 and 2020 the study traced the development of children and adolescents, and found that the advantages of living in cities with regard to healthy growth had shrunk across the world. Published in Nature, the paper indicate that in 1990, school-aged children and adolescents who grew up in cities with opportunities for better education, nutrition, sports and recreation were a few inches taller and had higher BMI than their rural peers. By 2020, however, the BMI averages rose for most countries except sub-Saharan Africa and south Asia, where the BMI rose faster in rural areas.
data.arabicTitle: وجدت الدراسة أن العيش في المدن ليس بالضرورة مفيدًا لنمو الأطفال

news.title: Rural kids in wealthy countries now grow taller than children in cities, study finds

collectionItem.title: Rural kids in wealthy countries now grow taller than children in cities, study finds

data.summary: Some health benefits of urban living for children may be diminishing globally, particularly in affluent countries like the US, UK, and France, according to a study by the Jameel Institute at Imperial College London, led by scientist Majid Ezzati. The research, published in Nature, analysed trends in child and adolescent height and body mass index (BMI) across 200 countries from 1990 to 2020. Previous studies showed that urban areas provided better education, nutrition, and healthcare, resulting in taller children compared to rural areas in wealthy nations. However, the urban advantage has shrunk in the 21st century due to improvements in height for children in rural areas. Dr Ezzati emphasised that addressing growing inequalities, especially for the poor, through initiatives like supplementary incomes and free school meal programmes, is crucial regardless of whether children live in cities or rural areas.
data.arabicTitle: توصلت دراسة إلى أن أطفال الريف في البلدان الغنية أصبحوا الآن أطول من الأطفال في المدن

news.title: Can creative arts projects help people deal with trauma from personal or group conflict?

collectionItem.title: Can creative arts projects help people deal with trauma from personal or group conflict?

data.summary: The role of creative activities and projects to help people recover from trauma associated with personal or group conflict was a strong theme of the 2023 Creative Brain Week at Trinity College Dublin in March. Various speakers presented powerful examples of how being involved in creative activities can improve physical and psychological health while building valuable social connections. Speakers included Christopher Bailey, co-lead of the Jameel Arts & Health Lab, the World Health Organisation’s (WHO’s) first ever arts and health laboratory, and Nils Fietje, WHO regional office in Copenhagen, both of whom highlighted how creative projects can be undervalued in medicine and emphasised the deficit of measuring the value of artistic interventions on health. Launched in New York in February 2023, the Jameel Arts & Health lab aims to remedy this by amplifying scientific research into how the arts can improve health and wellbeing.

news.title: Allurion announces appointment of MIT Distinguished Professor for AI and Health Regina Barzilay to scientific advisory board

collectionItem.title: Allurion announces appointment of MIT Distinguished Professor for AI and Health Regina Barzilay to scientific advisory board

data.summary: Allurion, a company dedicated to ending obesity, announced it has appointed Regina Barzilay, AI faculty lead at the MIT Jameel Clinic, to its scientific advisory board, chaired by Professor Bob Langer. Allurion generates millions of data points on consumers from over 60 countries who use the company’s platform to lose weight. Regina and colleagues on the advisory board will help drive cutting-edge AI across Allurion’s business to leverage data to improve outcomes for consumers. Dr Shantanu Gaur, founder and CEO of Allurion, commented, '[Regina's] experience at the intersection of AI and healthcare to improve patient outcomes is unparalleled and will be vital as we expand the use of machine learning and natural language processing in the Allurion Virtual Care Suite and Iris AI Platform'.

news.title: From international trade to interest rates, macroeconomics is in yet another tail spin

collectionItem.title: From international trade to interest rates, macroeconomics is in yet another tail spin

data.summary: In response to the Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR) calculation that a new trade deal between the UK and the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) would only add 0.08% to the size of the UK economy, despite the fact that the share of CPTPP countries' world output—not including India and China—is near to that of the European Union, Paul Ormerod argues that the UK trade perspective reveals shortcomings in contemporary understanding of macroeconomics. Whereas microeconomics has made a lot of progress over the past thirty years to understand how individuals and companies behave, the same cannot be said of macroeconomics. Ormerod points to the illustration of this provided by co-founders and co-directors of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) and Nobel Laureates, Abhijit Banerjee and Esther Duflo, in their book 'Good economics for hard times'.
data.arabicTitle: من التجارة الدولية إلى أسعار الفائدة ، فإن الاقتصاد الكلي في اتجاه آخر

news.title: Fest presents ‘The journey: A music special from Andrea Bocelli’ April 2-6

collectionItem.title: Fest presents ‘The journey: A music special from Andrea Bocelli’ April 2-6

data.summary: The Sedona International Film Festival will join theatres around the world to present the world premiere of Paramount's ‘The journey: A music special from Andrea Bocelli’ showing 02-06 April 2023, at the Mary D Fisher Theatre. Andrea Bocelli partnered with Community Jameel in 2019 to launch the Andrea Bocelli Foundation-Community Jameel Scholarship at the Royal College of Music (RCM) in London, supporting talented musicians to attend the schools world-leading Opera Studio. In ‘The journey’, Andrea and his wife Veronica travel on horseback along Italy’s Via Francigena, an ancient road traveled by pilgrims for centuries in the footsteps of the apostles and saints. Along the way, they are joined by friends including 2019 Bocelli-Jameel scholar, Clara Barbier Serrano, as well as Michael W Smith, Tori Kelly, Tauren Wells and TAYA for world-class musical performances in some of Italy’s most magnificent venues and majestic locations.

news.title: Boost the economy by offering routine NHS surgery at the weekend | Report

collectionItem.title: Boost the economy by offering routine NHS surgery at the weekend | Report

data.summary: As the British health service faces challenges overcoming a significant patient backlog, a new report by the Institute for Public Policy Research (IPPR) and LCP Health Analytics suggests that the NHS should offer routine pre-planned operations at the weekend to reduce the record waiting list and help boost the economy. Lord Darzi of Denham, advisory committee member, Community Jameel and consultant surgeon at Imperial College NHS Trust and the Royal Marsden NHS Foundation Trust agreed that the report highlights 'compelling policy levers' that policymakers can use to reduce the backlog and echoed arguments that there is both a convincing moral and economic case to 'go further and faster' in working through the NHS backlog of patients.
data.arabicTitle: عزز الاقتصاد من خلال تقديم جراحة NHS الروتينية في عطلة نهاية الأسبوع - تقرير

news.title: What the world bank can do about climate change

collectionItem.title: What the world bank can do about climate change

data.summary: As the World Bank undergoes a change in leadership and prepares to adapt its mission to address global warming, it should not only provide financial resources, but also enhance its ability to generate evidence-based solutions and bring them to policymakers’ attention. As a guiding example, research by Esther Duflo, co-founder and co-director of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) in India pointed out that, contrary to common belief, India has some of the strictest environmental regulations in the world, but lacks the ability to enforce them. Duflo's team show how devising proper mechanisms to address weak state capacity, unreliable contract enforcement and institutional corruption can significantly improve emission outcomes. It is here, in the design and implementation of policies to address institutional shortcomings, that the World Bank could add enormous value, in addition to investing in renewable energy and other climate-friendly technologies.
data.arabicTitle: ما يمكن أن يفعله البنك الدولي بشأن تغير المناخ

news.title: Royal College of Art launches CLIMAVORE x Jameel partnership with Cooking Sections for unique sustainability research

collectionItem.title: Royal College of Art launches CLIMAVORE x Jameel partnership with Cooking Sections for unique sustainability research

data.summary: A new three-year partnership between the Royal College of Art (RCA), Community Jameel and the London-based former Turner Prize nominees Cooking Sections has been announced by the institution in the hopes of using architecture as a tool to advance our knowledge of agriculture-related sustainability practices in the built environment. The initiative is being led by Cooking Sections co-founders Alon Schwabe and Daniel Fernández. The school’s new CLIMAVORE x Jameel at RCA partnership will focus on two projects which 'reimagine how we eat as human activity changes the climate by developing new methodologies and enhancing policies around the globe'. Both projects will offer research fellowship opportunities to postgraduate students while exploring 'how nature-centred food systems can be developed with communities in drylands and wetlands that are subject to particular seasonal stresses' in the form of site-specific case studies in Türkiye, France and Italy, respectively.
data.arabicTitle: الكلية الملكية للفنون تطلق CLIMAVORE x جميل شراكة مع أقسام الطهي لأبحاث الاستدامة الفريدة

news.title: DART VADAR harnesses the force of enzymes for better RNA drugs

collectionItem.title: DART VADAR harnesses the force of enzymes for better RNA drugs

data.summary: For decades, researchers have faced challenges in developing RNA-based therapies for diseases that only affect a single organ or cell type, wherein the full-body immune response caused by mRNA vaccines is not necessary to combat the disease. Researchers at MIT and Wyss Institute at Harvard University, including Jim Collins, Faculty lead at MIT Jameel Clinic, have developed a new system to overcome this roadblock called DART VADAR, which uses an enzyme that edits RNA in the human body to trigger the translation of a genetic payload in response to the presence of a specific molecular marker of disease and/or cell type. The technology has the potential to enable the development of highly specific treatments for a variety of diseases. The study was reported in Nature Communications.
data.arabicTitle: يستخدم DART VADAR قوة الإنزيمات لتحسين عقاقير الحمض النووي الريبي

news.title: DART VADAR alters the deal for precision RNA-based therapies

collectionItem.title: DART VADAR alters the deal for precision RNA-based therapies

data.summary: First identified in 1961, mRNA therapies are nothing new, and researchers have been trying to master targeted treatments using mRNA for decades. Now, scientist Jim Collins, Faculty lead at MIT Jameel Clinic, and his colleagues at Harvard Wyss Institute believe they're on the cusp of the next stage with the development of a novel engineered RNA sense-and-respond circuit named Detection and Amplification of RNA Triggers via ADAR (DART VADAR), which seeks out a specific molecular marker of disease for highly specialized treatment. DART VADAR works by detecting small amounts of RNA molecules of target interest within a given sample, even when mixed with larger amounts of other RNA molecules. The development could have important applications in medical diagnosis and treatment, allowing early disease detection. The technology is still in its early stages of development, but Jim Collins and his colleagues are optimistic about its potential.
data.arabicTitle: DART VADAR يغير الصفقة للحصول على علاجات دقيقة تعتمد على الحمض النووي الريبي

news.title: 33% of India’s youth aren’t in employment, education, or training. Most of them are women

collectionItem.title: 33% of India’s youth aren’t in employment, education, or training. Most of them are women

data.summary: According to the latest Multiple Indicator Survey (MIS) report of the Indian government’s National Sample Survey Office (NSSO), 15.4% of young men aged between 15 and 29 are not engaged in either education, employment or training (NEET), compared to 51.7% of young women. Economist and author Lekha Chakraborty, a professor at the National Institute of Public Finance and Policy, cited the prevalence of early marriage as one of the main drivers of this gender skew, and based her view on a 2013 study by co-founder and co-director of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL), Abhijit Banerjee and his colleagues, which highlighted how marriage is an economic decision for many women in India, one that their families often consider a wiser investment than education or training. Addressing these challenges requires a multi-pronged policy approach to change societal attitudes towards women's education and work, and to empower women to make their own choices about their education.
data.arabicTitle: 33٪ من شباب الهند ليسوا في وظائف أو تعليم أو تدريب. معظمهم من النساء

news.title: Speeding up drug discovery with diffusion generative models

collectionItem.title: Speeding up drug discovery with diffusion generative models

data.summary: A team of researchers, advised by Professor Regina Barzilay at the Jameel Clinic, the epicentre of machine learning and health at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), has developed DiffDock, a molecular docking model that has the potential to discover new drugs faster than traditional methods and reduce the risk of adverse side effects. A paper introducing this groundbreaking model will be presented at the '11th International Conference on Learning Representations'. DiffDock's unique approach to computational drug design represents a paradigm shift from current state-of-the-art tools used by most pharmaceutical companies, presenting a significant opportunity for revolutionising the traditional drug development pipeline.
data.arabicTitle: تسريع اكتشاف الأدوية بنماذج منتشرة

news.title: RCSI researcher awarded EUR 4.3 million to establish health research centre

collectionItem.title: RCSI researcher awarded EUR 4.3 million to establish health research centre

data.summary: Professor Edward Gregg, a leading population health scientist, has been awarded EUR 4.3 million from Science Foundation Ireland (SFI) to fund a new research centre at Royal College of Surgeons Ireland (RCSI). Formerly professor of diabetes and cardiovascular disease epidemiology and researcher at Jameel Institute, Imperial College London, Edward will lead a team of 13 new researchers to help reduce the burden of chronic diseases. Named Converge, the new centre will aim to transform the way population-level data and research platforms are deployed in Ireland to prevent and reduce the burden of chronic diseases such as diabetes and obesity. Researchers at the new centre will collaborate closely with the World Health Organisation, Imperial College London, the US Center for Disease Control and Prevention, Maynooth University, the University of Galway and the HSE.

news.title: AI chatbots can diagnose medical conditions at home. How good are they?

collectionItem.title: AI chatbots can diagnose medical conditions at home. How good are they?

data.summary: As more people turn to chat-based AIs for medical advice, it remains to be seen how these tools stack up against—or could complement—human doctors. According to Marzyeh Ghassemi, a computer scientist at the Jameel Clinic, the epicentre of machine learning and health at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), while AI chatbots could be a valuable tool, they should not replace the expertise of trained medical professionals. In particular, Marzyeh highlights the lag of regulatory bodies to catch up with the pace of AI development and deployment, and is concerned that chatbots will perpetuate racism, sexism, and other types of prejudice that persist in medicine—and across the Internet.

news.title: Diminishing health benefits of living in cities for children and teens

collectionItem.title: Diminishing health benefits of living in cities for children and teens

data.summary: The advantages of living in cities for children and adolescents’ healthy growth and development are shrinking across much of the world, according to a new global analysis of trends in child and adolescent height and body mass index (BMI) led by Imperial College London and published in Nature. The research, by a global consortium of more than 1500 researchers and physicians, including Majid Ezzati, research lead at Imperial's Jameel Institute, analysed the height and weight data from 71 million children and adolescents (aged 5 to 19 years) across urban and rural areas of 200 countries from 1990 to 2020.

news.title: A battery-free sensor for underwater exploration

collectionItem.title: A battery-free sensor for underwater exploration

data.summary: Fadel Adib, principal investigator at the Abdul Latif Jameel Water and Food Systems Lab (J-WAFS) at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), has developed a battery-free sensor for underwater exploration. Designed to harvest power from radio waves, the sensor can monitor water temperature, pH levels and other environmental factors in real-time, and has the potential to revolutionise ocean exploration by providing researchers with a cost-effective and environmentally friendly way to collect data. In particular, the sensor could benefit aquaculture by monitoring water quality and improving fish farming practices. Fadel's research interest is developing innovative technologies and algorithms for wireless perception, networking and sensing. His 2019 J-WAFS funded research project, 'Learning food and water contaminants using wireless signals', developed a sensor that uses wireless signals to determine food quality and contamination levels.

news.title: How states can promote food security as the public health emergency ends

collectionItem.title: How states can promote food security as the public health emergency ends

data.summary: The COVID-19 pandemic brought about federal policies that provided benefits for health, nutrition and food security for many US citizens. As the pandemic recedes, these policies are also coming to an end. Vincent Quan, co-executive director of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) North America, emphasises the importance of food security remaining a federal policy priority. In addition to making some pandemic-era policies permanent, Vincent suggests investments in programmes that support local agriculture, increasing access to healthy foods in underserved areas and expanding nutrition education programmes. By taking these steps, he argues, states can help ensure that individuals and families have access to the resources they need to maintain healthy diets.
data.arabicTitle: كيف يمكن للدول تعزيز الأمن الغذائي مع انتهاء حالة الطوارئ الصحية العامة

news.title: Opinion: New federal funding alone won’t be enough to help students catch up in the classroom post pandemic

collectionItem.title: Opinion: New federal funding alone won’t be enough to help students catch up in the classroom post pandemic

data.summary: While USD 122 billion in federal funding for education under the 'American rescue plan act' is a step in the right direction, policy experts argue it is not enough to help students catch up after the COVID-19 pandemic. Vincent Quan, Co-executive director of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) North America, emphasises the need for targeted interventions that address the specific needs of students. Quan suggests that the federal funding should be used to support research and pilot programmes that can be scaled up to benefit more students, and argues that ongoing policy evaluations are necessary to ensure that the interventions are effective and that resources are being used efficiently.
data.arabicTitle: الرأي: لن يكون التمويل الفيدرالي الجديد وحده كافيًا لمساعدة الطلاب على اللحاق بالفصل الدراسي بعد الوباء

news.title: Tackling counterfeit seeds with “unclonable” labels

collectionItem.title: Tackling counterfeit seeds with “unclonable” labels

data.summary: The trade of counterfeit seeds can lead to significant agricultural losses and economic damage. MIT researchers, including principal investigator at the Abdul Latif Jameel Water and Food Systems Lab (J-WAFS), Benedetto Marelli, are working to develop "unclonable" labels that can distinguish authentic seeds from fake ones. Marelli and colleagues developed a technique to print labels that use multiple layers of inks with varying optical properties, making them difficult to replicate. The labels can be read using an application and have the potential to revolutionise seed authentication and traceability. Marelli's research projects, including those funded by J-WAFS, have developed new technologies to minimise food waste, enable agriculture in marginal lands, rapidly detect food contamination and precisely deliver payloads in plants.
data.arabicTitle: معالجة البذور المزيفة بملصقات "غير قابلة للتقسيم"

news.title: AI image generator Midjourney blocks porn by banning words about the human reproductive system

collectionItem.title: AI image generator Midjourney blocks porn by banning words about the human reproductive system

data.summary: Midjourney, an AI-powered image generator, has been criticized for banning words related to the human reproductive system in an attempt to block pornographic content. Marzyeh Ghassemi, a principal investigator in MIT Jameel Clinic and assistant professor at the University of Toronto, believes that this approach is misguided and may even exacerbate existing inequalities. She argues that algorithms like Midjourney are only as unbiased as the data they are trained on. If the training data contains biases, then the algorithm will replicate those biases in its outputs. Marzyeh leads the Healthy Machine Learning Lab at MIT.
data.arabicTitle: يحظر مولد الصور بالذكاء الاصطناعي Midjourney المواد الإباحية عن طريق حظر الكلمات المتعلقة بالجهاز التناسلي البشري

news.title: Simon Fraser University announces 2023 honorary degree recipients

collectionItem.title: Simon Fraser University announces 2023 honorary degree recipients

data.summary:
The Simon Fraser University (SFU) has announced its 2023 honorary degree recipients, which include Esther Duflo, co-founder and co-director of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Esther was recognised for her groundbreaking research on global poverty and her experimental approach in designing and testing solutions to social problems. Her work has helped to identify effective interventions in areas such as education, healthcare and poverty alleviation. The honorary degree recognises Esther's significant contributions to the field of economics and her commitment to making a positive impact on the world. Other recipients of the SFU honorary degree include Indigenous rights advocate Cindy Blackstock, artist Ai Weiwei and neuroscientist Molly Crockett.

news.title: Al Palazzo delle Esposizioni, nel menu di "Climavore" c'è l'ambiente

collectionItem.title: Al Palazzo delle Esposizioni, nel menu di "Climavore" c'è l'ambiente

data.summary: The Climavore project, curated by Turner prize nominees Daniel Fernández Pascual and Alon Schwabe, known as Cooking Sections, has partnered with cultural institutions such as Tate and the Serpentine since its launch in 2020. Now, it arrives at the Palazzo delle Esposizioni, with ingredients and recipes designed to raise public awareness of the impact of food production and consumption. Climavore's arrival at the Palazzo heralds the launch of the duo's new research initiative, Climavore x Jameel at the Royal College of Arts (RCA) in London. Based in the RCA’s School of Architecture, CLIMAVORE x Jameel at RCA aims to reimagine how we eat as human activity changes the climate by developing new methodologies and enhancing policies around the globe.

Fadel Adib, principal investigator within the Abdul Latif Jameel Water and Food Systems Lab (J-WAFS) and assistant professor, MIT's department of electrical engineering and computer science and Media Lab, uses wireless technologies to sense the world in new ways, taking aim at sweeping problems such as food insecurity, climate change and access to health care. His research has even reached the White House, where in August 2015, alongside his thesis supervisor and MIT Jameel Clinic principal investigator, Dina Katabi, Fadel showcased a wireless device that uses Wi-Fi signals to track an individual’s movements to President Barack Obama.

news.title: How to pull carbon dioxide out of seawater

news.title: Power of thinking ‘small’: How small changes drive the big picture

collectionItem.title: Power of thinking ‘small’: How small changes drive the big picture

data.summary: Too much emphasis on the bigger picture can distract from the pragmatic and small base-level things that are critical to achieving larger missions. 'Thinking small' is a core finding of the economic research of co-founders and co-directors of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) and Nobel laureates Abhijit Banerjee and Esther Duflo. In their book, 'Poor economics' (2011) the authors warn against “Talking about the problems of the world without talking about accessible solutions”. Instead of imposing a grand solution on an enormous problem, they advocate for making small changes that can add up to a pragmatic solution.

news.title: Drought killed 43,000 people in Somalia last year

collectionItem.title: Drought killed 43,000 people in Somalia last year

data.summary: For five wet seasons in a row, Somalis waited for rain while their crops withered, their cattle perished and many people died of hunger or disease. A new report, released by UN agencies and the Somali government, estimates that there were 43,000 “excess deaths” in the country last year. Now Somalis are waiting for signs of the “Gu” rains, which are due next month. A slightly improved forecast and a recent drop in food prices offer hope, but even when this drought finally ends it will take years for indebted families to restock their animals and assets. Governments and aid agencies should start planning for the next one by developing strategic water points and infrastructure, argues Guyo Roba, head of the Jameel Observatory in Kenya, an international research partnership in Nairobi. Too often, their focus fades when the emergency does. “Immediately we get a better season, we go back and sleep,” he says.
data.arabicTitle: وقتل الجفاف في الصومال العام الماضي 43 ألف شخص

Efforts include extending BRAC's model Graduation programme to Rwanda and supporting participants' health, training, financial literacy and social empowerment. Research by Abhijit Banerjee and Esther Duflo, co-founders of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab, proves that this combination of support and resources is critical for long-term impact.

news.title: Detailed images from space offer clearer picture of drought effects on plants

collectionItem.title: Detailed images from space offer clearer picture of drought effects on plants

data.summary: Globally, drought is devastating vegetation and severely stressing water supplies, compromising food production and spiking food insecurity. Abdul Latif Jameel Water and Food Systems Lab (J-WAFS) researchers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), César Terrer and Wenzhe Jiao, are using remote sensing observations to build high-resolution systems to monitor drought, which can offer fundamental information on drought location, frequency and severity. In 2022, Terrer, assistant professor in MIT's department of civil and environmental engineering, received J-WAFS seed grant funding to produce drought monitoring systems for farmers.

news.title: J-PAL co-scientific director Amy Finkelstein recognised in 2023 STATUS List as a leader in life sciences

collectionItem.title: J-PAL co-scientific director Amy Finkelstein recognised in 2023 STATUS List as a leader in life sciences

data.summary: Co-scientific director of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) North America, Amy Finkelstein, was selected in STAT's 2023 STATUS List, an annual list world leaders in life sciences. Amy is recognised for conducting randomised control trials investigating health economics debates. In 2022, papers authored or co-authored by Amy showed that rates of opioid addiction could best be lowered by policies targeting regional variations in doctors’ willingness to prescribe the drugs and that an American’s risk of dying during the COVID-19 pandemic depended less on location than on racial or ethnic group, education level, and job sector.

news.title: This AI bot detects Parkinson’s by listening to you breathe

collectionItem.title: This AI bot detects Parkinson’s by listening to you breathe

data.summary: Parkinson’s is one of the most common—and destructive—neurodegenerative diseases in the world. In the United States, more than a million people will be diagnosed with the disorder each year, resulting in the loss of motor functions, cognition and memory. In a study published in Nature Medicine, principal investigator at MIT Jameel Clinic Dina Katabi and her fellow researchers trained an AI bot to observe and analyse a sleeping patient’s breathing patterns to detect neurodegenerative disease. The bot can also detect how severe a person’s Parkinson’s is, allowing doctors to tailor treatments to a person’s needs.

news.title: Easy money does not create a lazy poor: Abhijit Banerjee

collectionItem.title: Easy money does not create a lazy poor: Abhijit Banerjee

data.summary:
Debunking the myth that cash transfer programmes render recipients “lazy”, co-founder and co-director of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) and 2019 Nobel laureate in economics Abhijit Banerjee endorsed such welfare schemes for helping to combat poverty and inequality. Delivering a keynote address on the theme 'How to fight poverty? Kerala, India and the world', Abhijit, who co-authored a paper analysing data from randomised controlled trials of cash transfer programmes in 13 countries, opined the criticism that cash transfers render the poor "lazy" is the “starting point” in the neoliberal thinking about poverty.

news.title: Infectious disease modeller wins prestigious mathematics prize

data.summary: Jameel Institute epidemiologist at Imperial College London Dr Anne Cori has been awarded a share of this year's Adam's Prize for her outstanding work in modelling infectious disease outbreaks. Awarded annually by the University of Cambridge to UK-based researchers carrying out international research in the mathematical sciences, Anne is the sixth woman to win the prize in its almost 175-year history. Former winners include theoretical physicist professor Stephen Hawking (1966) and the 2023 prize is awarded for achievements in the field of mathematical and statistical epidemiology, a first since it was first awarded in 1850.

news.title: The big idea: Should governments run more experiments?

collectionItem.title: The big idea: Should governments run more experiments?

data.summary: There is a growing movement to apply randomised trials not just in healthcare but in other things government does. Overseas development is perhaps the most advanced example. The results of trials run by the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL), for example, have deeply influenced how the UK government spends aid money. Applying scientific rigour to government programmes seems unobjectionable, especially in a world of fake news and backfiring populist policies. So why hasn’t it taken off faster?

Banerjee reminded audiences that the poor "are not just victims, they have a sense of what they want, the life they want. Every time we make policies, we forget that they have ambitions, aspirations. news.title: Neural networks for drug discovery and design

collectionItem.title: Neural networks for drug discovery and design

data.summary: Drugs play a central role in modern medicine, but bringing new ones to market is a lengthy, expensive process. Industry and academia are exploring ways to streamline the complex drug development pipeline with artificial intelligence (AI). However, efficiently analysing chemistry and biology have favoured neural networks, whose structure naturally mimics that of molecules. Regina Barzilay, executive director of MIT Jameel Clinic, the epicentre of AI and health at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, predicts that neural networks is an area "that's going to grow for the field, and we will see a lot of computer science discoveries along the way".

news.title: Artificial intelligence is being studied to improve cancer care

collectionItem.title: Artificial intelligence is being studied to improve cancer care

data.summary: Lung cancer kills more people worldwide than the three most deadliest cancers combined. This is largely due to the fact it is hard to detect the disease at an early stage. Now researchers at the MIT Jameel Clinic, the epicentre of machine learning and health at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and Mass General Hospital have developed an artificial intelligence tool called Sybil, which can detect lung nodules on computerised tomograph (CT) scans and predict the risk of a patient developing a future lung cancer up to six years in advance.

news.title: ChatGPT is great at taking medical exams. But can it replace doctors?

collectionItem.title: ChatGPT is great at taking medical exams. But can it replace doctors?

data.summary: Despite its stellar capabilities in taking exams, ChatGPT is far from being employable in the medical field, experts say. ChatGPT is a large language model that predicts how sentences would fit together based on the text data it has been fed, but it does not mean the tool has “good judgment or common sense”, according to Ignacio Fuentes Ribas, executive director of the MIT Jameel Clinic, an initiative that develops AI machine learning technologies at the intersection of healthcare and life sciences at MIT.

news.title: The fight against antibiotic resistance is growing more urgent, but artificial intelligence can help

collectionItem.title: The fight against antibiotic resistance is growing more urgent, but artificial intelligence can help

data.summary: The increase of antibiotic-resistant bacteria globally causes up to 1.2 million deaths annually. Discovering new antibiotics has the potential to save millions of lives, but the process is costly, lengthy and difficult to achieve. Artificial intelligence (AI) can allow researchers to quickly design and assess new potential drugs. In 2019, researchers at the MIT Jameel Clinic, including Regina Barzilay, used a deep learning approach to identify the antibiotic Halicin, which had previously failed clinical trials as a treatment for diabetes.

news.title: Fighting poverty with development policies informed by science, the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab has helped more than half a billion people by 2022

collectionItem.title: Fighting poverty with development policies informed by science, the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab has helped more than half a billion people by 2022

data.summary: The Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) aims to support government development inititatives to reduce the spread of poverty in the world by ensuring that policy is informed by scientific evidence, enabling it to help more than half a billion people around the world by 2022. With a network of more than 250 affiliated professors at universities around the world who conduct randomised impact assessments to answer critical poverty questions, more than 540 million people have been reached through programmes and policies.

news.title: Education's changing face

collectionItem.title: Education's changing face

data.summary: COVID-19 left education systems that were already struggling even further from the goal of achieving quality education standards. However, as pointed out by most of the 220 professors affiliated with the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab, in a report by the SSIR, now is not the time to be crying over spilled milk. The key takeaway from the poll is that whatever metrics, expectations and goals were pushed forward before the pandemic, all of them must now be revisited, overhauled and made more realistic in view of the new normal.

news.title: Sybil: An artificial intelligence tool that can predict risk of lung cancer

collectionItem.title: Sybil: An artificial intelligence tool that can predict risk of lung cancer

data.summary: As lung cancer rates climb among non-smokers, new strategies are needed to screen and accurately predict risk across a wider population. Based on analyses of low-dose chest computed tomography (LDCT) scans from patients, researchers at the MIT Jameel Clinic, the epicentre of artificial intelligence (AI) in healthcare at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), have developed a new AI tool, known as Sybil, which can accurately predict the risk of lung cancer for individuals with or without a significant smoking history.

news.title: J-PAL at 20: Reflecting on two decades of promoting evidence for impact in Europe

collectionItem.title: J-PAL at 20: Reflecting on two decades of promoting evidence for impact in Europe

data.summary:
From two full-time staff in 2008 to an expanding team of roughly thirty people, J-PAL Europe has seen significant growth since its founding. Hosted at the Paris School of Economics, J-PAL Europe's work has developed from its early focus primarily on supporting research in France, to an expansive research portfolio that covers education, labour, finance, gender, governance and climate change. In parallel, its work has grown to encompass countries the region over—from Finland to Spain, and Turkey to the UK.

news.title: Balancing hope and despair in turbulent times

collectionItem.title: Balancing hope and despair in turbulent times

data.summary:
By Esther Duflo and Abhijit Banerjee, Nobel Prize-winning economists.

As long as we do the best we can, and appreciate life’s fullness, we will leave the world a better place for our children.

History offers many lessons, but the big picture is always a tangled skein of multicolored wool. Where it leads says a lot about the particular strand that we choose to follow — the optimist always finds a thread that the pessimist will carefully avoid.

news.title: Worst drought on record continues to ravage the Horn Of Africa

collectionItem.title: Worst drought on record continues to ravage the Horn Of Africa

data.summary:
Millions in East Africa are suffering from drought and starvation, as the longest and most severe drought on record drags on into the late short rains period. After five consecutive failed rainy seasons, experts predict that next year’s rainy period from March to May will also fail. Six failed rainy seasons is unprecedented.

Due to the drought, millions are facing crisis levels of food insecurity – many go days without food. Oxfam warned that food shortages will cause one death every 36 seconds till the end of this year.

Professor Elfatih Eltahir, the HM King Bhumibol Professor of Hydrology and Climate aT MIT and co-director, Jameel Observatory-CREWSnet, traveled to COP27 to present plans for the Jameel Observatory Climate Resilience Early Warning System (CREWSnet), one of the five projects selected in April 2022 as a flagship in MIT’s Climate Grand Challenges initiative. The Jameel Observatory-CREWSnet focuses on climate adaptation, the term for adapting to climate impacts that are unavoidable.

data.summary: In collaboration with Google Arts & Culture, the United Nations has published four unique digital stories commemorating the strength and vitality of the Yazidi people following the 2014 genocide in Iraq carried out by Da’esh. The stories were created by female survivors of genocide through a series of artistic workshops as part of the Yazidi Cultural Archives project, developed through a partnership between Yazda, a community-led organisation that aids survivors of genocide in Iraq and around the world, Community Jameel, CULTURUNNERS, the Office of the UN Secretary-General’s Envoy on Technology and the World Health Organisation, with support from the Iraq Cultural Health Fund, as part of the Healing Arts initiative.

news.title: J-WAFS awards $150K Solutions grant to Patrick Doyle and team for rapid removal of micropollutants from water

collectionItem.title: J-WAFS awards $150K Solutions grant to Patrick Doyle and team for rapid removal of micropollutants from water

data.summary:
The Abdul Latif Jameel Water and Food Systems Lab (J-WAFS) has awarded the 2022 J-WAFS Solutions Grant to Patrick Doyle, the Robert T Haslam Professor of Chemical Engineering at MIT, for his innovative system to tackle water pollution. His project involves a novel use of reusable, sustainable hydrogel microparticles to remove micropollutants from water. The problem of micropollutants, such as plastics derivatives, 'forever chemicals' and heavy metals, is pervasive, as they are present in more than 85% of rivers, ponds and lakes and can cause physiological damage when ingested over time.

Doyle and his team, which includes his co-principal investigator Rafael Gomez-Bombarelli, assistant professor in materials processing in the department of materials science, will use machine learning to optimise their microparticles, which can be recycled for continuous use. The technology has applications in municipal and industrial water treatment equipment, as well as household products. J-WAFS's USD 150K grant will allow the team to build protocols and prototypes and perform market research to develop a potential business plan. This could help millions of people by improving drinking water quality and provide an economically viable solution to the removal of persistent micropollutants.

news.title: Sounding the alarm, bolstering defenses

collectionItem.title: Sounding the alarm, bolstering defenses

data.summary:
An early warning system to help mitigate the impact of climate disasters in the world’s most vulnerable regions has been selected as one of the finalists for the MIT Climate Grand Challenges 2022. Professor Elfatih Eltahir, professor of Civil and Environmental Engineering at MIT and Lincoln Lab co-leads John Aldridge and Deborah Campbell, are developing a cutting-edge forecasting system called the Jameel Observatory Climate Resilience Early Warning System (Jameel Observatory-CREWSnet). According to Eltahir, "The basic idea behind the Jameel Observatory-CREWSnet is to reinvent the process of climate change adaptation. It integrates a lot of expertise and knowledge and tools that we have developed in different corners of the Institute, pulling them together to help those vulnerable communities."

news.title: How molecular biology could reduce global food insecurity

collectionItem.title: How molecular biology could reduce global food insecurity

data.summary: The effects of climate change, including changing temperatures, rainfall variability, shifting patterns of agricultural pests and diseases and rising sea levels all contribute to decreased crop yields, heightening the future food insecurity of a growing human population. Mary Gehring, professor of biology at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) is using her expertise in plant epigenetics to help crops develop climate resilience through a 2021 seed grant from MIT’s Abdul Latif Jameel Water and Food Systems Lab (J-WAFS). Her research aims at discovering how we can accelerate the production of genetic diversity to generate plant populations that are better suited to challenging environmental conditions. In 2023, Mary formed part of the winning team of the J-WAFS Grand Challenge Grant for a project seeking to enhance the efficiency of photosynthesis in order to increase crop yield.

news.title: Using soap to remove micropollutants from water

collectionItem.title: Using soap to remove micropollutants from water

data.summary:
Imagine millions of soapy sponges the size of human cells that can clean water by soaking up contaminants. This simplistic model is used to describe technology that chemical engineers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) have recently developed to remove micropollutants from water—a concerning, worldwide problem.

Patrick Doyle, the Robert T Haslam Professor of Chemical Engineering, PhD student Devashish Pratap Gokhal, and undergraduate Ian Chen recently published their research on micropollutant removal in the journal ACS Applied Polymer Materials. The research project is funded by MIT’s Abdul Latif Jameel Water and Food Systems Lab (J-WAFS) through a 2022 J-WAFS Solutions Grant and previously through a 2019 Seed Grant.
